I appreciate that in giving leave and speaking by leave there is no curtailment on what exactly is said. But surely, Mr Acting Deputy President, someone speaking by leave following the tabling of documents for which leave was originally given, must be required to confine his remarks to really the matter in issue, and the matter in issue is Senator Parer tabling some documents. Senator Faulkner spoke for some time about the tabling. He is now going much further—far and wide—on matters which really are not related to the matter that Senator Parer sought leave to speak on.
—Is this a point of order or a speech?
—What do you think it is? You take the choice.
—Order!
—I am sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President, I have been provoked by interjections from the other side.
—Senator Macdonald, I will seek to protect you, but I would ask you to very quickly come to the point of order that you rose on.

—The point, Mr Acting Deputy President, which I think you are now well aware of, and you have made this assumption yourself, is that Senator Faulkner is speaking well beyond the bounds of the matter for which he was given leave to speak. So I would ask that perhaps you might ask him to conclude his remarks on the matter for which he was given leave or otherwise that you rule him out of order.
—There is no point of order. Senator Faulkner is speaking by leave.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. What I want to say is this: because of the time at which Senator Parer came into this chamber and made his statement, there has not been an adequate opportunity for the opposition or other senators in the chamber to look at that documentation. There has not been and there will be no opportunity for senators to ask Senator Parer today at 2 o'clock at question time questions about these particular matters. So I have got to say, Madam President, I am very doubtful that Senator Parer has come clean.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam President. I certainly gave Senator Faulkner leave to speak because I thought he was going to apologise to the Baillieu family, and particularly to the family of the two Baillieu's—
—Senator Campbell, there is no point of order and that is not relevant to what is being discussed.
—I am just saying that that is why I gave him leave and I thought he would apologise, and I am waiting for the apology, as is the Baillieu family. The children of the Baillieu—
—Senator Campbell, there is no point of order. Resume your seat.

—Thank you, Madam President. What we do expect from Senator Parer is for him to have provided documentation and information to the Senate today that outlines all his interests, all his shareholdings in all the—
—Why do you assume he hasn't?

—Senator Alston says, `How do I assume he hasn't?' That is the whole point, Senator Alston: this material has not been made available to the Senate or senators before question time today. Of course we are very doubtful, given the fact that this minister has such a record of muddying up his private interests and his public duty. I would have thought this cowardly performance by the minister, coming in just a few minutes before question time and tabling that material, means the minister yet again stands exposed for not fulfilling his ministerial responsibilities. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, on 26 May 1996 you told Meet the Press that you had disposed of your BHP and Santos shares, presumably because you believed them to be in perceived or actual conflict with your portfolio responsibilities. Minister, why did you not at the same time reveal that you also owned shares in coal mining? Was it that you simply failed to comprehend that these shares could also result in a perceived or actual conflict of interest? Why did you resign as Chairman of Queensland Coal Mine Management Pty Ltd but fail to dispose of your shares? Minister, is it not the simple truth that you disposed of your BHP and Santos shares because these shares were in public companies and were thus readily discoverable, whereas your shares in private coal mining companies were not as readily discoverable?

—Madam President, it is quite true that I said, on whatever date Senator Faulkner quoted, that my wife and I had disposed of public company shares. I also point out that at that time I had fully disclosed to the Senate that the family had a trust company of which I happened to be just a beneficiary. I thought I made it very clear in this place last week that these shares were 16 non-voting shares.
—Why didn't you reveal them? That's all you had to do. Why hide them?
—Order! Senator Ray, there will be an opportunity for you to follow up these matters and now is not the time.

—Madam President, disclosure was made in accordance with the Senate requirements as I knew them at that time. I know that Senator Faulkner wanders on about three notices. The fact is that I was unaware that the Senate had changed the language used in disclosure, that rather than just put trusts down as investment-type trusts, more detail was required in regard to the trusts. As I pointed out last week in the Senate, if I had known that, I would have had no compunction in doing so. When I looked again at this information, which was drawn to my attention afterwards, I found that it includes other things as well. That particular trust does have real estate interests and does have public company shares which are non-mining shares. From my own perspective, with the facts that were known to me, I made full disclosure.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you confirm that in order to achieve the same dividend stream provided to you by QCMM Pty Ltd you would have needed to own 588,235 shares in BHP at a value of $9.2 million or 1.2 million shares in Santos at a value of $6.6 million, or indeed 4.3 million Telstra shares at a value of $16.7 million?

—Let me clarify this very quickly. The shares are non-voting shares. The dividends on those shares are determined by the ordinary shareholders of the company and they can decide whether you get nil, $5 or whatever figure you like. When Senator Faulkner decides to look at the documents I have tabled, he will find in those tables a letter from one of the leading stockbrokers in Nevitts pointing out the difficulties involved with those particular shares.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The coalition government inherited and is successfully turning around the $10.3 billion budget black hole which resulted from 13 years of economic mismanagement by the former Labor government. How have the government's sound economic policies resulted in expanded job opportunities, increased wealth generation and an improved living standard for all Australians?

—Madam President, I would certainly like the opportunity to answer the question because this is the big issue, this is the important issue: the matters that give hope and faith to the Australian people because they can rely on a government that has delivered so effectively in the areas of vital importance to them. In just over two years this government has delivered record low inflation so that businesses are now confident to invest and to expand. This government has delivered interest rate levels which are back to those of the 1960s and has delivered interest rates on housing loans which, for an average home owner with a $100,000 mortgage, allow a saving of about $330 per month.

answer.para: This government has been able to reduce the government deficit from the $10.3 billion that it inherited to a surplus by the time of the next budget and has been able to face up to the appalling industrial relations circumstances in this country, to provide a more harmonious industrial relations environment for the Australian work force through encouraging employers and employees to work together to provide terms and conditions of mutual benefit.

This government has been prepared to tackle Labor's unfair dismissal laws which created a major disincentive to employment and jobs generation and has addressed constructively the tariff protection issues in relation to the motor vehicle and textiles, clothing and footwear industries—the former, of course, has been responded to by industry positively.

It is worth reflecting that in just over two years this government, through its initiatives, has been able to contribute to the creation of an extra 235,200 jobs—something of which not only the government can be proud but no doubt all Australians appreciate. How has it done this? Through sound and sensible economic policies it has enabled growth, particularly within the small business sector. The small business sector has in fact been able to grow by some 6.5 per cent since 1995.

Private sector wealth has increased by some 11.8 per cent, the highest growth since 1989—or in other words, the highest levels of growth since before the recession that we had to have, something that we will not forget and that the Australian people will not forget.

This government, through its industrial relations reform to a background of positive economic growth, has been able to achieve an 85-year low in working days lost—a 43 per cent decline in the number of working days lost in 1997 alone. It is a fantastic performance from which all Australians gain benefit.

This has been to a background where the opposition, the Labor Party, has sought to frustrate every constructive move that this government has made. It sought to block and frustrate the budget initiatives the government took—

talk.start.para: —That's rubbish. That is absolute garbage, and you know it.

—to haul in expenditure and meet the $10.3 billion it inherited. It has, as you know, Senator Bolkus, fought against the unfair dismissal law reform which is so essential to the results that have been achieved. And it is continuing to fight against the unfair dismissal reforms that can go even further.

answer.para: I should remind the Senate that a recent survey by the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce of 700 businesses found that 85 per cent of small businesses had nominated unfair dismissals as a key factor affecting businesses of 15 employees or fewer. So there is finally a chance for Labor to face up to a real responsibility and contribute constructively to a better economic environment. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you mentioned expanded job opportunities: what specific job opportunities have been created by the coalition government?

—I use the one minute to remind the Senate of a few of the specific initiatives that are well worth remembering. The government's mutual obligation or work for the dole program has committed $100 million to fund 44,000 places in 1998-99 alone, with a total of $382 million over a four-year period—a major initiative which is being well received by the Australian people. This program includes assistance with literacy and numeracy training programs for 18- to 24-year-olds as well as an expanded job placement employment and training program.

answer.para: I remind you also of the government's new apprenticeship scheme which has committed some $560 million in incentives to employers, apprentices and trainees to support up to 220,000 places during the period of 1997-98 to 1998-99. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy. My question relates to the major thrust of your defence, Minister, against allegations of perceived or actual conflict of interest—that is, that you have derived no benefit from your coal interests since becoming a minister. Minister, will you confirm that Investment Management Pty Ltd has a total share allocation of nine shares, of which you own eight and your spouse owns one. Minister, is it not a fact that all dividends from your coal interests are paid direct to your company, Investment Management Pty Ltd, and are later disbursed to your family through a secondary process involving your family trust? Minister, hasn't Investment Management Pty Ltd, from a 16 share investment in 1993, received over $800,000 in fully franked dividends?
—Senator Faulkner has asked a number of questions. Any dividends to flow to the trust go to the trust.
—Try it again, Warwick!
—Order, Senator Ray. Senator Ray, do not shout across the chamber.

—They go to the trusts, and trusts are required to distribute moneys. They go to beneficiaries under the trust. As regards the nine shares, they are held in the names of the seven children, my wife and me.
—Investment Pty Ltd.
—Don't be distracted.
—Senator Parer, ignore the interjections and answer Senator Faulkner's question.

—As I have pointed out, these 16 non-voting shares were shares that were not part of the ordinary shareholders of the company. The company itself was controlled by at one time four major shareholders and now, in more recent times, it is controlled by three, because of a dispute between the shareholders. When it comes to decision making as to how much profit should be given to the non-voting shareholders—over which the current three shareholders have pre-emptive rights—that is their decision. The total amount—I presume Senator Faulkner is right; I have not gone and totalled it up—
—Don't worry about the $800 grand!
—When I came into that company in 1989, there was no hiding of it; everyone knew about it.
—Eight hundred grand! Everyone knew about it!
—Kim Il Carr or whatever his name is over there likes to interject—
—Senator Parer, just a moment. There are too many interjections in the chamber and there is far too much noise. Senator Parer, address your remarks to the chair and not to those who are interjecting.

—Thank you, Madam President. Senator, if you wish to have a look at the documents I have tabled, you will see the process that went through, in great detail. There has been no cover-up, no hiding—nothing whatsoever. I have been totally transparent. The only thing, as I mentioned the other day, in the absence of knowledge of that circular letter of 20 March 1997, I would have had no hesitation whatsoever in disclosing the interests of the trust company. And I said here the other day, I am only too happy to disclose that information.

answer.para: Going back to the issue of dividends; whatever the dividends are, it does not necessarily reflect, and in fact does not reflect, what could be the actual value of those particular shares. I asked the stockbroker the other day, `These are the conditions under which these shares are available to the family trust; what are they worth?' He said, `I'll give you $2.'
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You are not prepared to listen. You are on this trail of `let's wrap it up as a big deal'. It is no big deal. It is a form of arrangement that companies involve in where non-executive directors and shareholders are given the opportunity to participate in the profits.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you tell us about dividends. Given that your family trust has received over $800,000 in dividends on your $2 million worth of coal shares since February 1993, how much tax would you have avoided by holding the shares in your trust rather than holding them in your own name?
—Madam President—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Parer, we will wait for silence.

—The trust receives a number of forms of income: one is franked dividends, on which tax has been paid—okay? The other sorts of returns that come into that trust are property investments, on which full tax is paid. I will explain it to you again: under the taxation laws, you cannot hold dividends in trusts; they must be distributed.

—My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer, and it relates to a real issue—that is, fundamental tax reform. The need for tax reform is broadly supported throughout the Australian community except, of course, by the economic dinosaurs of the Australian Labor Party. Will the minister identify the unfairness of the current tax system and explain why taxation reform is so critical?

—I thank Senator Calvert for focusing on a really key issue which virtually all of the community believe is a very important issue, and they are looking to the major political parties to make their positions very clear on this.
—No GST!
—The fact of the matter is that Senator Cook is the only known Australian who thinks we have a first-rate tax system. Senator Cook, it will get lonely because no-one agrees with you.
—Tell the truth, why don't you?
—Senator Kemp, resume your seat. Senator Cook, I ask you to stop shouting across the chamber. It is not interjecting; it is just being disruptive and shouting.

—What I was going to point out to Senator Cook, and the very few people who happen to agree with his position in relation to the need for no tax reform, is that most Australians are very worried, and quite rightly, about the very high levels of personal income tax, particularly on the margins—the very high levels that the average Australian is facing on his marginal tax rate. That is one of the major problems with the current system.

answer.para: Another major problem with the current system is the wholesale sales tax, a system invented in the 1930s, which, as most people understand, possibly with the exception of Senator Cook, is riddled with anomalies and is causing great confusion and great cost to industry. The fact of the matter is that, for a variety of reasons, the current tax system is seen by many people to be unfair. As I said, they are facing very high levels of marginal taxation and, of course, the very old-fashioned wholesale sales tax system, which is exceedingly costly and hard to administer.

What we have seen in recent months is a lot of people in industry and in community groups putting forward their ideas for tax reform. To be quite frank, it is a very sad reflection on the Labor Party that so few members of that party have been prepared to come forward and constructively join this debate. There is an old saying which, I think, typifies the Labor Party: if you believe in nothing, you will say anything. Indeed, we had this over the course of the weekend when the shadow Treasurer was asked to put forward some of his views on tax reform. What he had to say caused quite a flurry in the media, I have to say, and certainly in New South Wales.

We had him saying that a Labor government would contemplate abolishing negative gearing. That is what the shadow Treasurer said on Melbourne radio. He said that negative gearing was certainly one option that could be contemplated. He followed that up with a comment that abolishing negative gearing was—
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I quote your shadow Treasurer. He said that abolishing negative gearing was `one of many, many options that we are certainly considering.'

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order. There are too many interjections on both sides of the chamber.

—We thought at last we had at least some hint of the possible tax reform program that Labor were putting forward and, as I said, it did attract a huge amount of interest around the community. But within 24 hours, the shadow Treasurer, Gary Evans, dropped this proposal. He then said, `We are not embracing a proposal to end negative gearing.' Of course we all hark back to a previous occasion—(Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, this is a very important national issue. Could you inform the Senate of the wide variety of advice you have been receiving on tax reform?

—Indeed, there is a very wide variety of advice we are receiving on tax reform but the Treasurer, Mr Peter Costello, did pass me a copy of a journal called the Gary—sorry, Madam President, the Gareth—in which he did not mention death duties and he did not mention negative gearing. But he did say that he would be very happy to supply some information on a GST. This—so far, apparently—is the only thing we have on the Labor Party tax reform package. It is a pathetic effort and the community rightly expect more from the Labor Party on this very important issue.

—My question is to the Minister for Resources, Senator Parer. In failing to declare your direct personal shareholding in QCMM (ESP) Pty Ltd, did you do so in order to hide that company's 760,000 share interest in the publicly listed company Pan Australian Resources NL?

question.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my right should allow Senator Parer to hear the question.

—Did you do so in order to hide that company's 760,000 share interest in the publicly listed company Pan Australian Resources NL? Did you tell the Prime Minister about your shareholding, through QCMM (ESP), in Pan Australian Resources? Did you tell the Prime Minister that that company is engaged in major exploration in Western Australia and Queensland for gold, nickel, diamonds, copper, lead, zinc and silver? Can you assure the Senate that you—as minister for gold, nickel, diamonds, copper, lead, zinc and silver—have never taken a decision to advantage Pan Australia? (Time expired)

—I explained in the Senate last week, when asked about this, that the whole purpose of QCMM (ESP) was, in fact, as a form of superannuation or retirement benefits. At the time, I thought that the thing had become defunct. Contributions were made, I think, for two years—but all contributions to it ceased in 1995.

answer.para: Let me say that I have had no interest in what shares that particular company has. If you want to talk about it, there is a company that has something of the order of—from memory—$4 million that applies to other people who have been part of the employee share program. That is what ESP stands for. I have had no involvement whatsoever in what it invests in. One of the things often spoken about, Madam President, in this place, are blind trusts. I have no knowledge whatsoever of any investments. On the information that I had on it, I had no record of any investments in Pan Aust. Now, maybe they do; maybe they do not. But I have no knowledge of that investment whatsoever.

talk.start.para: —Did you tell the Prime Minister?
—No. I did not know about it.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I took you to say you did not know about it, Minister. Is it also a fact that QCMM, the company in which you own $2 million worth of shares, owns 100 per cent of another company called Kiskin Pty Ltd which itself owns a further 3.7 million shares or 4.9 per cent of Pan Australian Resources. Is that a fact? As the web of deceit is growing by the day, Minister, have you disclosed all of your shareholdings—
—Senator Cook, I regard that as an imputation and would ask you to withdraw that phrase.
—I withdraw that phrase. Have you disclosed all of your shareholdings to the Prime Minister and how can you sustain any argument that these holdings do not constitute a flagrant conflict of interest?

—Let us correct the innuendo again. I do not hold shares in Kiskin. The family trust does not have shares; it has interest in what I understand is the Kiskin Unit Trust. And it is also my understanding that the Kiskin Unit Trust investments are pretty much limited to real estate and property investments. But I have no knowledge whatsoever of the interests of the family trust in another trust which is much larger, like one per cent. There is no involvement whatsoever in it since the days that I resigned from the major company and any subsidiary associated with it or any unit trust company associated with it.

—My question is to Minister Parer, Minister for Resources. Minister, I refer to the significant influence you brought to bear on Australia's climate change position in the lead-up to Kyoto. At the time the Australian Democrats, along with many governments, were astonished at the position your government took to Kyoto. Your stance was—

question.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my right, I cannot hear Senator Lees.

—Your stance was based on a completely discredited, blatantly biased and debunked ABARE modelling exercise and I ask: isn't it correct that your real agenda on climate change was to protect the Australian coal industry and, in particular, to increase exports of the Australian coal industry? Is that not exactly what you achieved? If this is not a conflict of interest, what is?

—The question of greenhouse and the greenhouse approach at Kyoto was a whole of government approach led very well, I might say, by Senator Hill. The whole of Australia gained from that outcome, including you, Senator Lees. Let us get more specific. You talked about the export market. Any decisions or agreements made by other countries in respect of what they use in their blast furnaces or what they use in their power stations is entirely a matter for them, not for us. We were looking at the Australian scene. From an Australian perspective, the concern in regards to greenhouse gas related to the power generation in our power stations from coal.

answer.para: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

talk.start.para: —And the worker, too—I'm with the worker! If we had gone down the Labor Party and the Democrat track, some hundreds of thousands of workers would have lost their jobs, not because of the export market but because of the generation of power in places like the Latrobe Valley, the Illawarra, the Hunter Valley and the Bowen Basin. They refer specifically to the generation of power in Australia. So you have got the steel industry, the aluminium industry and all those industries. As regards exports, the volume of coal that is exported depends on the demand in other countries for those sorts of materials for power generation, for the chemical industry, for the cement industry and for the steel industry.

answer.para: You are trying to track this back to a conflict of interest. The mine that I chaired does not sell any coal on the domestic market—it exports the lot—so any decisions that came out of Kyoto did not affect in any way the coal exports unless other countries decided that they were going to cut back. We had no control over that whatsoever. All that Senator Hill was doing was coming up with a solution that was in the interests of Australians, that was fair and equitable, and that preserved hundreds of thousands of Australian jobs.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I wish, indeed, that it had been the environment department that led us in the Kyoto debate, but, unfortunately, it was not the environment that was foremost on this government's agenda. Minister, you are basing those figures, which I think have been debunked well and truly by the Ombudsman, on the ABARE modelling exercise. Therefore, Minister, is one of the processes that you are going to review the entire ABARE modelling exercise? After all, the Ombudsman said that it was both blatantly biased and heavily in favour of the fossil fuel industry. It was on that document that you then jumped ahead and ran the argument at Kyoto. This was not losing jobs, Minister. Indeed, the whole argument at Kyoto was that, if we protected the environment, we actually increased jobs, particularly in the sustainable energy industries.

—First of all, I did not run the argument at Kyoto, Senator Hill did. Let me also correct a statement that you have made which is totally incorrect. The Ombudsman did not say the ABARE report was blatantly biased. I might say that a lot of the comments made by the Ombudsman have been taken on board by the ABARE people. Of course, as I have said here often—and no-one from that side has disputed this, because they have been in government and you never will be, Senator Lees—ABARE is there to give unbiased reports to the government of the day, whomever that government might be. The Ombudsman did criticise ABARE for the sort of nomenclature it used when it described the funding provided by some of the outside sources in the preparation of the Megabare model and, subsequently, the Gigabare model.

—My question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Senator Parer, I remind you of your statement to the Senate that, since resigning your chairmanship of Queensland Coal Mine Management Pty Ltd, you have had—and I use your words- `nothing whatsoever to do with the company'. How do you explain Mr Harold Shand's comment that not only had he met with you but the mine had been discussed in general terms? Minister, have you had contact with Mr Shand or any other company official from after question time on Wednesday, 11 March this year to now? If so, why did you initially deny it?

—The comment I made was that I have had no involvement with the management or the operation of that company. If you want to verify that in the documents that I tabled, you will see that Mr Shand has very clearly spelt that out and that any discussions that I have had with him have been of a general nature. There has been no reason for me not to.
—You heavied him this week!
—Here we have from the old Labor side over there—`You heavied him'. What a trade union remark.
—Order! Senators will cease shouting across the chamber.

—Since questions were raised of me last week certainly there have been queries raised by some of my staff with the company in respect of some of the detail—nothing more, nothing less, and you would not expect otherwise.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, in the light of your admission that your discussion with Mr Shand covered the Asian financial crisis, can you assure the Senate that you did not pass Mr Shand any sensitive government information relating to the Asian situation and its effects on the company's interests such as export coal prices? Can you give that categorical assurance to this chamber?

—Yes, I can give you the assurance. Let me tell you, Senator, and you should know because I think you were previously a minister of the resources department, that the information that comes to me from the department—which I might tell you, Madam President, is public knowledge the moment it hits the deck—comes to me in a consolidated form. It does not mention companies or anything like that whatsoever. As you would also be aware, in the main the major companies settle and they become the sorts of prices which others follow. I just reiterate that under no circumstances was there any sort of sensitive information. You talked about the Asian crisis: the only discussion was on the Asia meltdown—which, incidentally, you people on the other side have shown no interest in whatsoever. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment. Today, 10 western Sydney councils and 38 community groups representing the 1.5 million people of western Sydney released a damning report of the government's draft EIS for Badgerys Creek airport. These groups totally oppose any airport in western Sydney because of the impacts on noise, air and water quality, as well as lifestyle. What is the government's response to this united opposition to its proposals? In particular, does the government stand by the use of the Australian noise exposure forecast system used in the EIS for Badgerys Creek, knowing that this is the same system which was used for the third runway at Kingsford Smith airport and that it proved to dramatically understate noise impacts on residents?

—Of course, the whole purpose of the EIS process is to isolate, analyse and publicly debate the environmental issues that need to be considered in making a sound decision. It has been a widely held view for a long time that Sydney needs a second airport, and it would be irresponsible to plan otherwise. Badgerys Creek was the favoured location of the Labor Party and, as I understand it, the federal Labor Party at least continues to support the Badgerys Creek location.

answer.para: As you know, we looked at another possible site at Holsworthy and found that that should be ruled out quite early in the environmental impact process. We nevertheless found at the same time that the Badgerys Creek site was such that it justified further examination of the environmental issues, and that is what is taking place at the moment. It is a comprehensive process. It is a process that we believe will give public confidence in the final outcomes.

We want to see the development of a second airport for Sydney, but if it is to occur it has to occur in the environmentally best way possible. That is what this process is all about. If the people of Sydney are engaging in that process, then I applaud them for doing so. I look forward to reading the report that has been issued today. It may well help us in that debate.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The people representing the 1.5 million western Sydney residents are not engaging in the process. They have opposed the Badgerys Creek option. I ask the minister: will he and the government, notwithstanding the influence the Labor Party has on his thinking, now move to reassess the whole business of a second airport for Sydney in light of the needs of the 21st century and the other options which are available to the government, including new evidence from the civic leaders of Sydney and experts in this field from right around the world?

—I do not quite know what the honourable senator means in that regard. I think we are going to need air travel and we are going to need airports into the foreseeable future and, in the largest city in Australia, there has to be adequate airport capacity. I think the honourable senator is also incorrect when he assumes that all Sydneysiders in the west of Sydney are opposed to it. In fact, there are varied views. Some councils are in favour of it; some are opposed to it; some actually see new job opportunities, commer cial investment and other community benefits that can flow from investment of this type.

answer.para: But the important bottom line is that if commercial investments in transport infrastructure projects of this kind are to go ahead, they are to go ahead in the best environmentally possible way. That is why we have engaged in a uniquely comprehensive and detailed environmental impact study. We look forward to that reaching its ultimate conclusions because, through our commitment to that study, we can give confidence to the people of Sydney. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, as you are aware, your last published declaration to the Senate Registrar of Senators' Interests was lodged in May 1994 and was notable more for what it failed to disclose than for what it actually disclosed. But, in the interests of setting the record straight, Minister, can you advise the Senate of whether you have now amended your declaration to comply with the March 1997 requirements of the Senate Registrar, complied with the 1994 requirements of the Senate Registrar in so far as declaring your 44 shares in QCMM Group (ESP) Pty Ltd is concerned, and have amended your declaration to reflect your 1996 divestment of shares in BHP and Santos? Minister, if you have not amended your declaration as outlined, why haven't you?
—Let's go to the second question first. In 1994, when those declarations were made, there was no requirement actually through a trust company to list the shares themselves.
—These were 44 shares you owned.
—No, you are talking about BHP and Santos, and the instructions that I gave to my wife who ran the trust—
—You gave her instructions?
—Absolutely, because I said that it was important that we did not have any publicly listed mining shares, right?

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —No, to make sure, because she was responsible for the share portfolio. I indicated the other day here in the Senate that I was unaware—and so was my staff—of this change that occurred, and that if we had, we would abide by that. I have not changed in that, and I will.
—You've had 12 days!

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. My question to you, Senator Parer, was that if you had not amended your declaration, given the furore that has surrounded this issue, why haven't you? You have had now two weeks to amend the register in which, at least on this issue, you have said that you are in technical breach of the requirements. Why haven't you fixed it up, Minister?
—I have said I will and I will.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Let me start by saying that I note the minister's recent statements that, firstly, the ABC has an important role to play in the future of digital television and, secondly, the government will be wanting to ensure that the ABC does have fair access to the spectrum. Will both the ABC and SBS each receive full access to 7 megahertz of spectrum, allowing them to provide the enhanced service to all Australians that he has said he will give to the other free to air channels? Will the government provide the spectrum to the ABC and SBS free, as it is announced will be done for the commercial free to air commercial broadcasters? Will the minister provide an undertaking that the ABC and SBS will be fully funded for the digital conversion of all their production and transmission facilities?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We have not yet made any formal announcements on this matter. Let me say that I do support the proposition that the ABC and SBS should be treated separately. Indeed it was the Labor Party, as you will recall, under the current failed shadow treasurer, that was very keen to actually merge the ABC and SBS. We are not proposing to go down that path. Therefore, they each have their business plans. They have each made separate submissions. I think they each stand on their individual merits.

answer.para: I also think it is fair to say that there is no basis in principle for denying them access to the same quantity of spectrum that would be made available to the free to air networks. Similarly, I think it is also fair to say that if you go down the US and the UK paths then you proceed on the basis that spectrum is not charged for as long as it is used for the purpose of digital television. On that basis, the ABC and SBS are entitled to expect that they will have an equivalent treatment to the free to air networks.

As far as the cost of digitisation is concerned, we have had an independent survey commissioned by Arthur Anderson. I have only recently had a look at that document. I have had discussions with ABC management about its contents. I think I have made it clear to them and I think they agree that more work needs to be done to flesh out precisely what might be involved in the cost of digitisation. Certainly, if you want to take a global view you have to include not only the cost of digitising cameras, edit suites and post production facilities but also the cost of transmission. I do not believe we are in a position to make a judgment about the true cost of digitisation for the ABC in that regard.

Ultimately, the amount of money that might be made available by the government would depend to a significant extent on efforts that the ABC itself has made to minimise the cost that might be necessary. That is of course tied up with questions of outsourcing. I noted from what was said by one of the directors the other night that the ABC has reached close to 50 per cent of outsourcing for non news and current affairs. If that figure is accurate, then it suggests they are in the process of reducing the amount that might be required in-house because the cost of digitisation will be borne by the independent production houses and therefore built into the leasing or other arrangements that might be entered into by the national broadcasters.

There is still a way to go in looking at precisely what costs are involved. We accept that there will inevitably be additional costs flowing to all free to air networks from the conversion to digital. It is, I think, going to be a very exciting experience even though in some respects it is not possible to anticipate precisely what the ultimate business case might be, but certainly there will be plenty of opportunities there for all the free to air networks.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. There were two things in it, though, that I would like him to expand on a bit if he can. First of all, he mentioned the independent consultants Arthur Anderson's report. Will the minister be tabling that report or making it public? I think we would all be very interested in what was in it. Secondly, does the minister agree that, in principle, the ABC and SBS will need to be funded by the government for the changeover from analogue to digital for both production and transmission because otherwise it just will not happen?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We will certainly be wanting to ensure that it does happen. The ABC itself does not take the view that all funds need to come from government. Certainly, they are not asking for that. They have identified a figure to which they would like us to contribute, but it is significantly less than the full amount. I think you should proceed on the basis that the ABC itself is able to identify ways in which it can raise additional funds. Certainly, some of those might also derive from the ultimate opportunities that become available from digitisation. As far as the report is concerned, I do not have any intention of releasing that at the present time. I will have a look at it and see whether we might have a different attitude.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, can you confirm that you have indicated to the Prime Minister in your letter to him today, just tabled, that arrangements were made last Friday for you to divest yourself of your family trust interest by `vesting complete authority in our seven adult children under an amended trust arrangement'? Can you explain, Minister, how that is consistent with the Prime Minister's code of ministerial conduct, which says, `The transfer of interest to a family member or to a nominee or trust is not an acceptable form of divestment'? Why don't you comply with the Prime Minister's code? Why don't you resign?

—You are scraping at the bottom of the barrel, aren't you, with all the muckraking you can do! I do confirm that those arrangements are in the letter to the Prime Minister and I will tell you why they are. I made the point right from the word go that the reason for the setting up of this trust and its whole purpose was for the benefit of seven children, who are now adults—and there are some of us who when we work in business for 30 or 40 years do this in a way that is going to benefit our children. Amending it in this way, by transferring it to a new trust company in which neither my wife nor I have directorships or shares or are beneficiaries of, reflects legally what has been the case for quite a long time.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Parer, is not divesting yourself of these shareholdings a final admission from you that they result in a flagrant conflict of interest? The Prime Minister's code states:

question.para: Ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities.
You admitted guilt by doing that today. You have not complied with the code. You have ignored the code again because the code states:
The transfer of interests to a family member or to a nominee or trust is not an acceptable form of divestment.
You have breached the code again. You have no alternative, Minister, but to resign.

talk.start.para: —The whole purpose of disclosure whether it be in the Senate or for the Prime Minister's guidelines is to address conflict of interest. Not once has anyone on that side shown that in my ministerial capacity I have had a conflict of interest.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is too much shouting in the chamber.

—If you look through the documents from my department, that I have tabled today, talking about the decision making process you will find that there is no conflict of interest. What does conflict of interest mean? I will tell you what it means. It is something that you do as a minister that enhances your own financial position. I have never made a decision within my portfolio that has had that effect and it is very hard to see the potential to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. The government intends to seek a mandate at the next election to enable Australians to take a further stake in Telstra. Will the government use the overwhelming majority of the proceeds from floating the rest of Telstra to reduce Commonwealth debt? How does the government's position on these important issues compare with the record of the previous Labor government that sold both the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —That is a very important question from Senator Ferguson because there is an absolute chasm between the parties on this issue. We said prior to the last election that we would seek a mandate before we embarked on any privatisation of Telstra. We obtained that mandate and we proceeded to provide Australians with an opportunity to buy shares, which I am sure none of them regret for a moment.

answer.para: We have now sought the opportunity to seek to be in the same position after the next election. What is the Labor Party's position? They will say one thing and do another. What did they do in relation to the Commonwealth Bank? Before the 1990 election they said they would not sell it at all. They swore blind that they would keep it 100 per cent government owned. What did they do after that? They started to sell down. Before the 1993 election they swore blind that they would not sell any more. What did they do after the election? They sold even more.

What is particularly significant about this whole debate is the fact that there were a couple of stories written about what a former senior Labor minister told Mr Frank Blunt about Telstra being privatised in the early 1990s. Mr Blunt went on to say that he was still a very active person. You do not have to be too smart to work out who that was. The minister for communications at that time was Mr Beazley.

Mr Beazley was invited to go into the House and deny that proposition, but he has not. Never for a moment has he done that. What he did was call a press conference and say weasel words like, `I was leading the charge. I was doing this, that and the other and that time.' He said, `I have had a discussion with Mr Blunt and his recollection of events has confirmed mine.' If Mr Beazley is really saying that it was not him that talked about privatising Telstra let him have the courage to go into the parliament and say in front of the Speaker that, in fact, it was not him. He has never had the guts to do it.

talk.start.para: —Gutless!

—He is certainly not gutless in other respects, Senator Calvert! I noted with a great deal of interest that Mrs Kernot has recently been appointed to handle the Telstra issue. This is the shadow minister for the me generation yuppies, presumably the ones who have been into Telstra shares in spades. Mrs Kernot has said a few things about Mr Beazley and the Labor Party on this very issue. They are very pertinent remarks. She said, `I think Labor in opposition won't sell Telstra, but I'm more worried about Labor in government.'

answer.para: In other words, she knows that this mob lie their heads off. What she ought to be doing is keeping the bastards honest instead of lying down for Labor as she intends to do no doubt. She is so obsessed with getting on to the front bench and maybe one day having the opportunity to be in a position of power that she is not interested in the slightest about the remarks she has made. She said to Mr Beazley, `Listen, we are not buying these empty assurances. We're very dubious about commitments that are later breached.'

That says it all. If your own person nominated to get out there and argue your case does not believe the case what hope have you got? The fact is that this is utterly opportunistic. We are the ones who will apply the overwhelming proceeds of sale to retire debt. We will not splash it up against the wall as this mob did when they privatised Qantas and Commonwealth Bank—used it for recurrent expenditure. Now you have Mr Crean saying we would use it for everything else under the sun. They are not to be believed in any shape or form. We are the ones who accompanied the first sell down with a regional telecommunications infrastructure fund which you opposed. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is the government aware of any threats to this historic opportunity to wipe out 40 per cent of the Commonwealth's debts?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Yes. Funny you should mention that, because it is precisely Mr Beazley's debt. He was the finance minister at the time. He has no interest in actually bringing down any of that debt. They would simply use the proceeds for any expedient purposes that they saw fit. I will give you a classic example of how far off the mark they are. In arguing that Telstra should not be sold, the current shadow minister for communications said: `In daily life, every Australian relies on Telstra and therefore the government should retain control of it.' This is the ultimate in communist nonsense I would have thought. We rely on fresh air, we rely on clean water and we rely on roofs over our heads. The government should own all these things? It is a nonsense. They know it. They do not have a leg to stand on. They are not interested in doing anything other than trying to gain a few bits of support from the people who might be otherwise misled, by pretending that they do not understand why this is happening. They know it is happening in every other country in the western world, but they are not prepared to stand up and do the right thing.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), to questions without notice asked today relating to the financial interests of Senator Parer.

What Senator Parer has done today is come into the parliament a few minutes before question time and table certain documents relevant to the travails he has at the moment, the troubles he has at the moment. But you have to read Senator Parer's letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). That letter is dated today, 23 March 1998. You have to flick through the first few pages. You have to get to page 9 before you find out what Senator Parer is up to. It comes under the subheading `Revised arrangements'. Senator Parer's letter says this:

Accordingly arrangements were made last Friday by Brisbane lawyers, Corrs Chambers Westgarth and our accountants Howarths, for my wife and I to renounce any interest as beneficiaries in both family trusts, to resign all offices and directorships, and to vest complete authority in our seven adult children under an amended trust arrangement.

What that says is that Senator Parer's decision to divest means he is guilty as charged by the opposition of a conflict of interest. He is guilty as charged. What he has done is make a final admission that his shareholdings place him in an impossible position—a flagrant conflict of interest, a conflict between his public duty and his personal interests. Because of that, he has made a decision to divest through this mechanism. But look at the mechanism he uses. Let me quote it again. It says:
. . . vest complete authority in our seven adult children under an amended trust arrangement.

That is what Senator Parer's letter to the Prime Minister says today. But what do the Prime Minister's own requirements say about this particular matter? Let us not forget from day one—not when Senator Parer failed to disclose these shareholdings and his interests in his family trust but since the opposition has exposed his deceit in this matter and exposed the fact that he did have interests, very substantial interests, in a mining company in the same area where he has ministerial responsibilities—we have always pointed to the Prime Minister's discredited guide on key elements of ministerial responsibility. We have always pointed to that clause that says this:
Ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities.

That is what Senator Parer is supposed to have done. He has failed to do that. He has failed to declare those interests to the Senate register of pecuniary interests. He has failed to comply with the Prime Minister's own guide. Now he tries to slime and sneak and snivel his way out of this by proposing this form of divestment of his company to his adult children. He now says that he will vest authority in his seven adult children under an amended trust arrangement. The problem is that that is a clear breach of the Prime Minister's own guide. That is a clear breach of what the Prime Minister said he must do. The same clause of the Prime Minister's guide to ministerial responsibility that says that a minister who has business interests in the area of their portfolio responsibilities must divest them also goes on to say this:
The transfer of interests to a family member or to a nominee or trust is not an acceptable form of divestment.
What Senator Parer has done is propose a form of divestment that is disallowed under the Prime Minister's own guidelines. That is what the minister here has done.

We now have a brief opportunity to have a look at the material that Senator Parer tabled prior to question time today. He does not come clean at all. We do not know what all the details are in relation to his interests and his shareholdings. We have never believed that Senator Parer has been telling us all of the details before the Senate. What we say now is that this proves that Senator Parer is guilty as charged. The only issue remaining is the sentence, and there is only one appro priate sentence—that is, that Senator Parer should resign or should be sacked by the Prime Minister. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Senator Faulkner has lost it. He knows it, and so do the people behind him. Everybody in this chamber, everybody in the parliament, knows that Senator Parer is as honest as the day is long. There has been absolutely no conflict of interest. In spite of two weeks of muckraking and guttersniping by the Labor Party, they have not come up with one piece of concrete evidence about any personal benefit to Senator Parer over this matter. People are seeing this as simply another slimy Labor Party muckraking effort.

speech.para: The Labor Party were not so outraged as they are pretending to be now when Senator Bolkus, as the then Minister for Administrative Services, negotiated to move the audit office into the ALP-owned Centenary House. Where was all this feigned outrage at that particular time? Where was the outrage of the Labor Party when their leader Bob Hawke, a personal friend of Sir Peter Abeles, used the armed forces to crush a union at the time of the pilots' strike? Where was all of this feigned outrage at that time?

Where was the outrage when Mr Hawke used his position as Prime Minister to collect $1 million from four Western Australian business leaders? Why were you not objecting to that, Senator Forshaw, at the time? What about when then Senator Evans wrote the blue book on diplomacy using ANU academics without giving acknowledgment of their contribution? Where was the outrage with that? That was genuine fault. In the case of Senator Parer, there is not a thing wrong, nothing has been proved. We could go on to Mr Keating, of course, and his conflicts of interest which are absolutely legend.

talk.start.para: —Good old Warren!

—As my colleague says, there was Mr Warren Anderson. We all know about the length that Mr Keating went to and the conflict of interest at the time, and not a word from these people who are so vocal today.

speech.para: It is a pity that Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, has gone because I want to raise an issue for him to clarify for me. There were a couple of serious questions today. The Labor Party have not asked one question this session on jobs, on tax reform, on the real issues that are important to Australian people, but there was one that came from the Democrats about the ABC. If there is this question about supposed conflict, I want Senator Alston to have a look at the former general manager of the ABC. You will remember David Hill, lovely fellow. He used to be involved with the North Sydney Leagues Club. He was not a bad fellow. Do you remember that he got his contract paid out?

talk.start.para: —That's right.
—He got his contract paid out. Everybody thought that the ABC had sacked him because he was pretty hopeless at the job.
—Like Grahame Morris?

—He was sacked. Do you know what the ABC board did? They paid out his contract because his term had been terminated before time. We all thought that was probably fair, but then we found out in the estimates committees—and I remember asking about this—that in fact Mr Hill was not sacked; he resigned of his own volition. That is fair enough. Nobody wanted him and he knew the time was up, but he resigned.

speech.para: Tell me, Senator Cook, you are the alternative finance minister, why if you resign does your employer still pay you out for the balance of your term? What was it—$300,000 or $400,000 that Mr Hill got? We should look into that. You have spent a lot of time going through the ASC records and Senator Parer. You will probably want to go back and have a look through the ABC records and at this guy who resigned of his own free will, according to him and according to the Senate estimates Hansard. Who pressured the ABC board to pay him out? This is all in this New South Wales Right stuff, Senator Forshaw. You perhaps would know the answer to that. Did anyone pressure the ABC board into paying out Mr Hill $300,000 or $400,000 when he, of his own volition, resigned from a position? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —That was a big red herring. If there is something wrong, investigate it, set it right, but do not try to change the focus of this debate. What do we have here? We have Senator Parer looking much like the bloke who has been pulled aside by the speed cop who says, `You were speeding,' and he says, `I wasn't driving,' and then the cop says, `But you're the only one in the car.' That is what you have here. Senator Parer gets sprung, and then he confesses. Then he puts out a notice saying that all the things we have been saying are right. That is what we have here. Let us not confuse the matter. Do not blame us. These are your guidelines imposed on you by your Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who now disobeys them.

speech.para: There is a clear conflict between public duty of a minister and private interests of this minister. That is a conflict of interest that not only should not be the case but also should not be seen to be the case. The Prime Minister is on the record often enough saying, `It's got to be not only a conflict but also an apparent conflict.' Other people went on that basis, why doesn't Warwick Parer go?

The whole situation here is quite simple. Just before question time we had a pre-emptive strike, an attempt to try to clear the air by dropping a massive paper on the table and saying, `That clears it all up.' We are told it will take an hour to photocopy these documents before we can actually look at them, but it does not clear the air. What we have seen now in fact complicates the issue. What is the whole truth here? Remember, when you talk about the truth, you do not just talk about the truth—you talk about the whole truth and nothing else but the truth. What we got was never the whole truth.

Let us have a look at what the whole truth is here. We, of course, know that he is a minister in charge of an area where he owns a private company and he regulates the behaviour of companies in the area which he controls. We know that he has $2 million worth of shares in one of the companies in the industry he regulates. We know as a minister he is in regular contact with the chairman and managing director of his company. We know that he visited Japan and spoke to two other partners associated with his mining company. We know he sat through the native title debate in this chamber and did not declare his interest, despite the fact there was a clear conflict of interest between his ownership of that company and native title claims.

Now the web of deceit widens even further. Enter the company Pan Australian Resources NL. Who is Pan Australian Resources, the new entry into this debate? It is a company listed on the stock exchange worth $11 million.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, on a point of order: during question time, Madam President made Senator Cook withdraw certain words. He has now flagrantly, in disregard of her request, repeated those words during his speech and you, Madam Deputy President, ought require him to withdraw.
—Senator Cook, if you have said anything unparliamentary, would you please withdraw it?

—I said `web of deceit'. That is what we have here but, if you rule those words unparliamentary, I will withdraw them. The plot has thickened to the extent now that very serious suspicions are raised about deceit. Do you prefer that, Senator?

speech.para: Let me go to Pan Australian Resources. It is a company listed on the stock exchange worth $11 million. The Parer family trust holds 16 shares in QCMM Pty Ltd, and QCMM Pty Ltd in turn holds 100 per cent of Kiskin Pty Ltd, and Kiskin in turns holds $3.7 million or 4.9 per cent of the issued capital of Pan Australian. That is the truth, the whole truth.

The truth was, `I don't have any interest in a mining company.' When you go through the blinds and who holds what in whom, who holds what in whom and who holds what in whom again, you find that Kiskin holds $3.7 million or 4.9 per cent of the issued capital of Pan Australian, and Kiskin is Pan Australian's third largest shareholder. It is not insignificant.

Also, Minister Parer directly holds 44 shares in QCMM Group (ESP) Pty Ltd. QCMM Group (ESP) Pty Ltd in turn holds 726,355 shares, or 0.96 per cent, of the issued capital of Pan Australian Resources. Collectively, he holds over five per cent of Pan Australian. Pan Australian is involved in major gold, nickel, copper, lead, zinc and silver exploration projects in Western Australia and Queensland. At no stage has Senator Parer declared his indirect interest in this mining and exploration company, yet he regulates activities in all those areas of gold, nickel, copper, lead, zinc, silver and so forth. He is not just the minister for coal; he is the minister for resources. Why didn't he fess that up? Why didn't he tell the whole truth? Why did he just tell that truth which he knew we had found out and argue that as a protection? Why did he say that he did not know he had to put it in his declaration? Ordinary Australians cannot get away with not knowing what the law means. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On 3 October 1995, Senator Faulkner was awarded the Dr Meredith Burgmann award for the most hysterical outburst at an ALP conference. I think he should also receive an award for his hysterical outburst today. What we know about Senator Faulkner is that, whenever he does not have the facts on his side, he becomes hysterical because he thinks that somehow noise is going to obviate the need for evidence and facts.

speech.para: The reality is that nothing at all has been pinned on Senator Parer. The reality is, as was so very well put in the Australian Financial Review of 19 March 1998, that the Labor Party are bereft of policies. They have no policies, no solutions and no alternatives, so what do they do to try to create an atmosphere of activity? They engage in muckraking. They have defamed people who have been dead for half a century—the Baillieu family—but when they are proven wrong, when their researchers are shown to be wrong, do you think they have the good grace to come back into this chamber and apologise and say, `We made an honest mistake'? No, it is beyond them, because there is no sense of decency about their attacks on this government. As former Senator Richardson said about the Labor Party's modus operandi, they do `whatever it takes'. They will do whatever it takes to try to score an easy, sleazy point.
This article that I referred to in the Australian Financial Review of 19 March 1998 was very telling, and allow me to quote from it. It states:
And does the opposition usually ask stupid, nitpicking questions? Well yes, actually.
Of the 67 questions asked by the Opposition in the House so far this year, 22—
or pretty well one-third—

had nothing to do with policy, and only five dealt with the economy, 12 with employment and four with industrial relations. The Opposition Leader, Kim Beazley, asked one question on the economy and one on employment.

That ought to tell the Australian people that these are the priorities of the Leader of the Opposition, the would-be Prime Minister, the alternative Prime Minister. In all that time, he asked one question on the economy and one on employment.

But what about all the sleazy allegations that have been made against Senator Parer and others? Mr Beazley is in there fighting thick and hard but, when it comes to alternative policies for this country, he is nowhere to be seen. Of course, the situation is no different in this place. As the article stated:
Of 583 questions asked in 1997, only 79 dealt with jobs, debt, inflation, budget issues, small business and the general economy.
And guess what it said about Senator Faulkner?
The Senate Leader, John Faulkner, asked three questions on unemployment.
That was what he asked for the whole year. That is his commitment to creating jobs in Australia

What is Senator Faulkner doing? He is attacking a man who, by his own investments and by his own diligence, has created jobs for Australians—something Senator Faulkner has never done and something Mr Beazley has never done. Senator Parer has earned export dollars for this country—something Senator Faulkner and Mr Beazley have never done. Indeed, Mr Beazley's record is creating the huge foreign debt that the Commonwealth faces and that we, in a very appropriate manner, are seeking to repay.

So if the Labor Party wants to talk about standards, let it just reflect on who would be the Attorney-General under its regime. It would be Senator Bolkus. He would have direct responsibility for the Skase matter—the man who deliberately leaked Federal Court documents that prejudiced the whole action. That is the Labor Party's standard. While Senator Bolkus remains on the front bench of the Labor Party, the Labor Party has no right in any shape or form to seek to attack the propriety of our ministers, let alone someone who is so highly regarded as Senator Parer.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to be able to join in this process today of taking note of Senator Parer's answers and, in particular, to note his answer to me regarding this government's stance on greenhouse. Since Senator Parer became the minister for resources, it has been, much to the Democrats' annoyance, really a ministry focused on the coal industry, a ministry focused on the past. Yes, it is focused on an industry that is very important, but in emphasising this one particular part of his portfolio he has deliberately ignored—indeed, I would go so far as to say he has not just ignored but has undermined, de-funded and actually worked against—alternative energy sources.

speech.para: If we look at his answers to questions asked today, again he seems to wish to completely avoid and indeed pretend, I suspect, that he does not really understand the link between our stance at Kyoto and the interests in his industry. Let us just look at the position that the Australian government took. We were the only country to go over there and argue for an increase. That was certainly an embarrassment to those people in Australia who care about these issues, to the conservation movement, to indeed the many scientists who have worked for many years and I believe have shown this government very clearly where our future should lie.

Senator Parer suggests today that he does not understand the link between coal exports and the fact that we went to Kyoto trying to destabilise the world agreement, trying to pull the world back from the 10 per cent or eight per cent reductions. We then went down even below that to the point where we have managed to get it to where we can actually increase ours, and the rest of the world got away with a lot less, particularly Europe, than those of us who care about the environment had hoped for.

Let us look at the link. If the world is not pushed to do something about alternative energy—in other words, people are going to be allowed to rely on coal into the future year after year—if people are going to be allowed to continue using coal, then our coal exports, which are the minister's priority, will flourish. It is no good, Senator, to stand up in this place and say it is all about jobs. Firstly, the ABARE model has been debunked. It has been shown to be the nonsense that it really is. No-one else in the world believes it. It has never been substantiated by any other modelling exercise anywhere. We see very clearly that this government's emphasis on coal has detracted from the adoption of a range of alternatives. For every percentage point we managed to pull back at Kyoto—away from that 10 per cent reduction which was I believe the minimum—we see the benefits to Australia of coal exports and not the benefits in jobs. The coal industry is rapidly shedding jobs. I suggest that if this minister does not understand that he should read the daily papers for a few weeks as we see coalmine after coalmine closing down and many of those that are staying in business shedding workers.

I also suggest that this minister does some reading on alternative energy; that he looks to Europe, particularly to Denmark and the new jobs being created there in wind energy; that he looks at the papers that have been prepared on what Australia could be doing in the solar industry area, particularly the fact that we are leaders in a range of different facets in this field at the moment and that we should now be exporting this technology far more than we are doing. Part of the reason that we are not able to have the strong base here in this country on which to build and to export is because this government is simply not encour aging that industry, amongst others. Just look at the penetration of solar hot water services in this country. We see an appalling rate of somewhere around four per cent for a country where 65 to 70 per cent of our landmass is suitable for solar technology.

If we can see the direct link between this minister's mind-set on the coal industry, how it has to be protected to the detriment of all other industries, and we now understand what his personal links are to the coal industry, I have to ask him: what is a conflict of interest, if this is not? I look forward to the opportunity later on in the MPI to go through other areas, other decisions of this government, that are directly linked to the support for the coal industry and against alternative energy sources.

talk.start.para: —I thought that was a very interesting contribution from the Leader of the Australian Democrats. Senator Lees talked about solar energy and all the rest of it. The fact is that when Senator Parer has been attacked for his so-called conflict of interest, no-one has accused him of a direct conflict of interest. I say that sincerely because there is no direct conflict of interest. One thing I know about Warwick Parer, and I have known him for 10 years, is that he is not a dreamer like the Democrats—he is a realist.

speech.para: The realism in this case is that if Senator Robert Hill had gone to Kyoto and succumbed to the world pressure, with the Democrats and Duncan Kerr running around and working against the national interests of Australia, the couple of mine closures that we have seen with the loss of a few thousand or a few hundred jobs in Australia would have been something like 90,000 to 100,000 jobs. If the Democrats are serious about being interested in jobs, they would have taken a different view and proposed different criteria to what they are pushing now. The only alternative they can come up with to the reality of coal power is solar power. We all know how expensive that is. Sure, there have been a lot of investigations and the like into solar power, but the realistic view is that, at this point in time, if we had not got those concessions in Kyoto 100,000, Australian jobs would have been lost in Australia. That is the reality of the whole thing.

I was most disturbed to hear the word `deceit' being used about Senator Parer. There is one thing about Senator Parer: he is not deceitful and he is an honest man. There is no question about that. Senators opposite should take the time to look at the documents that he tabled today. In the letter to Prime Minister, he establishes where he is coming from when he says:
Starting with no special privileges I worked hard to establish and develop business interests and I make no apology for my success.

And neither should he. Neither should anybody who is a successful businessman. It seems to me, all that ever happens in this place, if you are a successful businessman, is that the minute you put your head up it is the old tall poppy syndrome—knock them down! I think the taxpayers out there who are subsidising politicians to act on their behalf should look at the value they are getting from Senator Parer who has that business acumen. He is a self-made man who has shown his ability to make a dollar, which is more than we can say for senators opposite. All they know is how to spend money.

When they come in here and start talking about conflict of interest, I start thinking about some of the people on their side over the years. Alan Griffiths owned a sandwich shop while he was the minister for industry. Was that a conflict of interest? They would probably say no. Graham Richardson: remember him? He was a director of radio station 2HD while he was a minister. He did not declare his interest. I do not suppose he thought it was necessary. He used his position as minister to try to influence the President of the Marshall Islands on behalf of his cousin. Do you remember that? Talk about conflict of interests!

We all knew that former Prime Minister Bob Hawke was a great personal friend of Sir Peter Abels. What happened when the pilot strike was on? Who put the defence forces in to help Ansett and Qantas? Really and truly, these people on the other side are criticising someone who is a self-made man, who has come in here and tabled all the documents and has not been proven to have any conflict of interest whatsoever. As some of these documents from his sharebrokers show, he gave instructions when he was appointed as minister, without any question at all, concerning Kathi Parer. I says here:
Upon Senator Parer's appointment as Minister in 1996, she instructed us to review the share portfolio held . . . where there may be an appearance of conflict of interests—

They have gone ahead to do that in good faith and I believe that Senator Parer did exactly that. He is a man of honour and trust and, as the Minister for Resources and Energy, he would want there not to be any doubt at all that he had any conflict of interest. I do not believe that has been proven, nor will it be proven. I am sure he will continue to be a very good Minister for Resources and Energy for this country.

talk.start.para: —On 27 November 1997 I reported to the Senate on the committee's concerns with this determination which related to uncertain provisions concerning the development of and legislative authority for guidelines and the steps to be taken to ensure general public awareness of the determination. The minister has now agreed to amend the determination to provide for a mandatory provision to remove the uncertainty and has provided other information which meets our concerns.
