It is not even something you can think of in terms of considering whether or not there is a revenue implication because it is not a matter of extending the family wider; it is simply a matter of addressing an issue of discrimination within existing family structures.
—The Australian Democrats advise the chair that we will be supporting the Greens (WA) amendments.

—The Labor Party has considerable sympathy with this amendment. The problem with it is this. You look at me somewhat askance, Senator Kemp. I hope I am not misinterpreting the somewhat surprised, if not curious, look on your face. What is being argued here is that the recognition of same sex unions ought to be extended to single sex unions, if that is the right terminology. We are not particularly opposed to that idea—although it does have some implications for tax law—but putting it up in the context of this legislation does create for us a problem.

speech.para: My advice is that the areas in which it would have an impact, if this amendment were carried, extend far beyond the legislation now before the chamber and impact on things such as the superannuation spouse rebate, the family tax initiative, Austudy benefits, zone rebates, the Medicare levy calculation, and so on. It seems to me, if this matter is to be given the attention in the chamber that obviously the support for it suggests it ought be given, then perhaps it ought to come forward as a measure to be dealt with on its own, rather than being dealt with in the context of a particular bill without us being aware of all of the implications of what we are voting on. Therefore, I reserve my position on it. The opposition will not be supporting the amendment.

talk.start.para: —There is always a reason from the Labor Party. Sometimes it is, `No, we can't just deal with this particular measure in this particular bill because we want it to be more applicable if we are going to do it.' Here we have a situation where we are saying, `Okay, we would like to change the legislation in a way that is more encompassing and starts dealing in reality with honesty and with the discrimination that has been felt by a number of people in our society in a systematic way.' The opposition is suggesting that the problem is not just the Taxation Laws Amendment (Trust Loss and Other Deductions) Bill 1997 —so it is not the `tax rorts for heterosexuals bill' in particular. They are saying the problem is that we are now suggesting, if we make this amendment, that it could be more generally applied.

speech.para: The irony is that we have had complaints when we have mentioned these various bills and the opposition has said, `Oh no, we can't do this piecemeal because we want to deal with it in a general sense'. `We can't deal with it because it has a revenue implication.' `We can't deal with it this time because it has implications for other bills.' There is always an excuse. There will be a time at some stage when the Labor Party will actually have to deal with its own policies, and there will be a time when the Labor Party will have to explain to the gay and lesbian community in Australia exactly why they are acting in this way.

talk.start.para: —I totally support the amendments put forward by Senator Margetts. I think the argument put forward by the opposition is bereft. What it says serially, in response to the amendments that are consistently brought forward by Senator Margetts, is that this needs to be dealt with in some other way. But the opposition never comes up with that other way, despite its ability to do so and despite its so-called commitment to the end of discrimination against gay and lesbian people. It always says, `Another day, in some other form.' I am not only sick of that but I brand it as nothing other than discriminatory.

speech.para: Let me declare an interest: I have a male partner. I understand the situation that people who feel strongly about this take. I take umbrage on their behalf at the fact that we have not only the government not accepting the logic of Senator Margetts's amendment but the opposition saying, `This is not important enough for us to deal with tonight. Indeed, it has beneficial flow-on effects for those people who are discriminated against. Therefore, we have to be wary of it.'

I would have thought that the argument Senator Cook put forward is an excellent one for voting for this. The process has to start somewhere. Time and again, on social justice legislation, Senator Margetts has said that it is socially unjust to have this constricted definition of spouse which effectively includes a partner but not when it is a same-sex couple. It is effectively restricted to heterosexual couples. That is of itself discriminatory.

Long ago this parliament passed legislation recognising that to single out people who are homosexual is to be discriminatory. Senator Margetts time and again says, `Here is the opportunity to end this discrimination, to turn it around, at least in so far as the legislation before the Senate is concerned.' The government sets its steely face against the end of such discrimination, and the Labor Party says it is not the time to do it. Well, when is the time? I challenge the Labor Party to come forward with the broad brush legislation it repeatedly says is going to end this discrimination.

Short of that, I have to say that we are involved in a discriminatory process involving perhaps a million Australians. And that is not what the Labor Party stands for. It may be something we can associate with Liberal Party ideals, although, as I recollect it, it was the Fraser government that led the way in this country in bringing to an end the discrimination against homosexual people as far as relationships are concerned under the law. But it did not go far enough. I challenge the government to make sure that that end to discrimination goes right through the laws of the Commonwealth.

I challenge the Labor Party to do the same. And I ask the question: when is the time for this? After 13 years of Labor in office, after two years of the coalition in office, there is no sign of adopting, for example, the very strong move by the Democrats to end such discrimination. It is left to the smaller parties to continue to try to pick away at this. It is a challenge to the big parties, the alternative governments. Is the Labor Party going to come up with an election platform which says, `We will act as a matter of priority to end this discrimination'? Is the government going to announce in its election policy that it is going to end this discrimination and in fact show good faith by doing it before the election or is it going to stand indicted for its continuing discrimination on a whole range of social justice issues such as this? I commend Senator Margetts on her forbearance, her persistence and her stoicism, because it is a very important matter which she raises. I only wish we were getting a more positive response from the major parties in this place.

talk.start.para: —I must say I am rather disappointed in the views that have just been expressed. I want to take a moment on behalf of the Labor Party to express a clear understanding of where we stand on this matter.

speech.para: We have just had two contributions, both of which began by attacking the Australian Labor Party for the reply I gave a moment ago on this measure. The first and most obvious point I want to make is that neither of those attacks—and they were modified a little later on, I must say—went to the government. It just so happens that we are not in government, we have not introduced this legislation to the chamber and we are not the ones who command a majority here most of the time. I would have thought that if there were sincerity in the points of view being expressed then they would have been expressed to the government whose legislation this is and not to the Labor Party who are manfully trying to improve the legislation. I put that as a first, albeit not very significant, point. But it is a point of demeanour or approach. You people get up and are pleased to slag off at the Labor Party. It is not our legislation; it is the government's legislation. If you have something to say, why don't you say it to the government?

talk.start.para: —I know what their policy is. What is your policy?

—I will take that interjection on board in a moment and reply to it. Secondly, what did I say when I responded to this amendment? I thought I gave a fairly reasoned and sympathetic response to the principle being enunciated here. I do not for one moment resile from those words. In fact, when I look at what previous spokespersons have said when this amendment has been trotted up I think I might have given a more sympathetic response to it than my predecessors have, although by no means do I gainsay the position that they put.

speech.para: I do think that this is not a matter that can seriously be dealt with in a particular bill like this. Let me explain that. I have just been reading a book about the origins of democracy and the emergence from feudal states and kingdoms into a democratic form of many middle European and eastern European countries.

talk.start.para: —Who's it by?
—It is by Norman Davies, and it is called Europe: A History .
—It's a good book. I've just started it.

—I doubt that you have, Senator. I think that that is a frivolous interjection. I doubt that you have, because you display none of the scholarship that is inherent in this book, I might say, with the greatest of respect. One of the points made in the book is that in early democracies there was such a thing as `facade democracies', where people claimed they had a form of democratic society but it was really a facade; there was no practice of it. I must say that there is a facade here of principle. I have not been approached by Senator Margetts. I am not aware that the shadow Treasurer has been approached either. I am not aware that there is any letter to the Labor Party raising this matter.
—When? When—appointment.

—No. It is too late, Senator Margetts, while I am replying to what you said about us, to now want to say, `Well, let's go and have an appointment.' If you were serious about this, you would not have waited for me to stand here and defend myself from an attack by you; you would have done something constructive about it. Facade principle: pretend to the principle; go to the grandstand; wave to the crowd; pretend you are trying to do something when your actions are no constructive move to correct what you see as the injustice.

speech.para: A logical first step would be to go and talk to those parties who you think might be an ally in this case and develop a meaningful dialogue about getting a majority here and in the other place to actually change the law, rather than drop an amendment on us at the last minute, without any attempt to explain it to us, and say, `Here, cop this!'

As I have said, there are implications for several pieces of legislation: the spouse rebate, the superannuation spouse rebate, the family tax initiative, Austudy benefits, zone rebates and Medicare levy calculations—to name just a few. I do not know what the implications of this amendment are across all of that. I do not know that anyone knows and, until there has been a good look at it, I do not know that anyone can say with confidence what their position is with respect to the full implications of it.

There is a principle here. I do not know what the cost element is either, and I do wish to know that. All I am saying is this: I tried to give a sympathetic response to your amendment, and I believe I did. I think I tried to give a constructive response as well, and I said, `Well, this is a serious matter; take it up properly.' I do not appreciate, on behalf of my party, being attacked that the Labor Party is somehow reactionary or recalcitrant in this; we are not. We have a good record on social reform in this country, and I do not expect anyone to criticise it. But I do think that if people are serious, they should not be en gaged in facade-ism. They should be engaged in positive, constructive acts to achieve an outcome. While they do not, and while they criticise, I must say that I find it difficult to treat the argument seriously.

If we want to go on to debate this further, I am happy to engage in it further. But I would suggest that it may well be better if we saw some constructive initiative rather than the damaging criticism that has been made up until now.

talk.start.para: —I cannot let that go unanswered. With bill after bill, the Greens have tried to negotiate the principles of decency with the ALP. The fact that, bill after bill, you are finding excuses should not be the basis for you criticising the Greens for trying to put a model on the table to put pressure on whichever government is in power.

speech.para: The fact that you did not do anything for 13 years means that you have the opportunity of agreeing to a model which might, if the sky falls down, if the pigs fly, be something that you would take as a principle into government. We have, bill after bill, talked to you, tried to talk to the Labor Party, about putting this principle into practice. If that is not something positive, I do not know what is.

We have worked with the Democrats. Senator Brown has got up on several occasions to try to find out what has happened to the inquiry on discrimination based on sexuality. We are working on this issue on a daily basis. What is not positive about that? We are on the crossbenches; we, of course, are not in government, but we have the ability to speak out. I think what you have said tonight is an atrocious, appalling cop-out.

talk.start.para: —I will add to that: the accusation of facade-ism is disgusting. The Labor Party ought to be more responsive to the repeated efforts by the gay and lesbian community to get the end of discrimination into legislation, and all parts of legislation, in this national parliament. To accuse the Greens of facade-ism, that is, of putting up a front they do not believe in, after what I had to say earlier, is, to me, just rotten politics.

speech.para: In my earlier contribution, I said that I did not expect better of the government. I think they have lost the carriage of justice which the Fraser government got under way in this realm. I think they have such reactionary strength within their ranks that it is a hopeless case, although we must never give up on them. But for the Labor Party to say that this is facade-ism and to accuse me, and in particular Senator Margetts, who has, as she said, raised this issue time and time again, and for it particularly to hide behind the specious argument that there may be other beneficial flow-ons to other pieces of legislation from the disadvantaged and discriminated sector of our community, is to lose itself as far as having any shred of justification for the position it takes is concerned.

I reiterate: to vote against this amendment by Senator Margetts is to vote for the inherent discrimination of the constrictive definition of spouse, which says that this applies to heterosexual relationships but not to homosexual relationships in this country. That is directly, on the face of it, unarguably discriminatory. Senator Margetts has brought forward this amendment to end that discrimination.

Whatever the argument, the Labor Party cannot say it has not been lobbied for many years on these issues, on ending discrimination in all areas of social justice law, by the community that Senator Margetts is defending.

The Democrats moved long ago for a Senate committee to look at this matter. Essentially, the findings were that discrimination should be ended. Here is an opportunity to move in that direction, and the best we get from the Labor Party is, `You go out and get the community, which is already exhausted by lobbying us and getting no result, to come and lobby us.' I do not cop that, Senator Cook.

talk.start.para: —I never said that either.
—That was my interpretation of what you said.
—Well, it was wrong.

—It is not wrong; it is right. I will not wear it. If the Labor Party is going to vote against this amendment, it is voting for discrimination. That is the short and the long of it. You move the way you want to, but that is how it is. No argument you have brought forward tonight is going to alter that fact.

speech.para: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (10) Schedule 1, item 11, page 126 (lines 10 to 12), omit the item, substitute:
Insert:
(c) Division 270 of Schedule 2F to this Act;
Insert:

(4AL) A person who makes an election in accordance with subitem 21(2A) or 22(3) of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Trust Loss and Other Deductions) Act 1998 must retain the election until the end of 5 years after the election was made.

Amendment 10 new item 11 will correct a minor drafting error by ensuring that the proposed amendment to section 170 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 will fit in with the new drafting recently put in place as part of the tax law improvement project. Amendment 10 new item 11A is part of the package of amendments that will implement new transitional arrangements for making family trust elections. The item will add a provision to the record-keeping provisions of the income tax law requiring an entity that will make a family trust or interposed entity election in 1997-98 to retain that election for five years. This is the standard record retention period for income tax matters.
Amendment agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (2) Schedule 1, page 127 (after line 8), after item 12, insert:
Notwithstanding any other provision in this Act, the Commissioner is to apply the following principles to the administration of this Act:
(a) the Act has operational effect from 1 October 1997 and applies only to unused losses on and from that date;
(b) no penalty available under this or any related Act applies to any use of trust losses or other deductions between 1995 Budget time and 1 October 1997;

(c) any loss incurred by a trust before 1995 Budget time which has been declared in the trust's taxation return for the 1994-95 year of income remains available for ongoing reduction of trust taxable income, without penalty, until the loss is fully utilised;

(d) any loss incurred by a trust before 1995 Budget time which has been declared in the trust's taxation return for the 1994-95 year of income is exempt from the income injection test in Division 270.

As senators know from my remarks in the second reading debate, it was our understanding that it was the view of all the witnesses that trafficking in trust losses ended on 9 May 1995. It was also made very clear by the witnesses that they believed that the bill introduced in October 1997 was quite materially different from that foreshadowed by Labor on 9 May 1995 and later prepared. It was that view that things were so materially different which occasioned a great deal of distress. In the remarks made by Senator Cook earlier and confirmed a couple of times, it is Labor's view that this bill is quite different in a number of respects from that that they intended to move.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills reviewed the question of retrospectivity and came to the view that this bill did infringe the rights and liberties of individuals. The Democrats and, indeed, other political parties in the Senate have a long history of not supporting retrospective activities. The view was expressed by Senator Bishop today—correctly—that at times tax retrospectivity has been approved. However, since this bill was directed originally at trafficking in trust losses and since the belief was that trafficking in trust losses had ended on 9 May 1995 after Treasurer Willis's announcement, our view is that a substantial number of trust losses which have been legitimate to date are put at risk by the dating of the bill.

We believe that the bill requires amendment to ensure that losses on foot at 9 May 1995, rather than being at risk of extinguishment by the bill, remain available and without taxation penalty. The stated intention of this government is that the bill will apply, effective 9 May 1995, to losses on foot at that time—some two years and 10 months ago and covering some four consecutive tax years. To eliminate its retrospective operations a simple operational clause needs to be inserted or the existing operational references need to be amended so that the bill is only effective from the time of its introduction to parliament—in other words, from the time that the profes sions and their clients understood its operation; that is, 1 October 1997. Its operational effect limited to extinguishing losses on foot at that time is to allow the test and penalty provisions to apply to unused losses from that date only.

The effect intended by limiting the retrospective operation of the bill is to ensure that losses used between 9 May 1995 and 1 October 1997—that is when the impact and the detail of the bill was unknown to trust users—will attract no penalty from the bill. We have got together, therefore, amendment No. 2. The entire purpose of that is to prevent retrospective application to matters other than trafficking in trust losses. I accordingly look for Senate support for amendment No. 2 on sheet 871.

talk.start.para: —I cannot remember the number of times that I have been in this chamber—especially when we were sitting on those crossbenches rather than on these crossbenches—that we have heard outrage from a range of frontbenchers and backbenchers from the coalition in relation to retrospectivity. It was a principle upon which they stood very strongly. Senator Murray is not suggesting that we allow a tax rort to be gotten away with retrospectively, but he is suggesting that the normal ability to write off tax losses without the trafficking in tax losses be available retrospectively.

speech.para: If we are after retrospective behaviour modification or the implementation of what was suggested as the publicly stated basis for these actions several years ago when Labor was in power, what is being asked for by the Democrats is perfectly sensible. If they were here, there are several people from your side that I can think of who would be strongly supporting this. I do not know why, but they do not seem to be here at this time. I would like to think that this is a principle that has been strongly enunciated by the coalition on many occasions. In this particular instance, we are not talking about not backdating a tax rort, but of legitimate practices that have gone on and have been encouraged by government departments in terms of rolling over tax losses.

talk.start.para: —The Labor Party will not be supporting this amendment. Ralph Willis's last budget as Treasurer announced this legislation in May 1995—or at least it announced the original, virile, muscular version of this legislation, and not the watered-down piece of legislation that we have in front of us now. The then opposition—now the government—referred it to a committee, held it up, and we were not able to legislate it. Back then we said, `Here is an area of tax avoidance that needs to be dealt with promptly. When bills relating to tax are announced, they ought to come into effect immediately. That is the end of the rort period. Bang! This is where the government is going to go. All those who engaged in this sort of behaviour, beware, because anything you do from now on will be taken away from you.' That is a consistent principle on taxation, and it would be wrong for us to depart from that now. We will not and, therefore, we will not be supporting this amendment.

speech.para: The other reason why we will not be supporting this amendment is the cost of it. One has to have regard to cost. The tax system in Australia is constructed to raise a certain amount of revenue in order to meet the costs of delivering public services and benefits to the community. Quite clearly, if some revenue is not raised in one way, then inevitably it will be raised in another.

One of the points made by my colleague Senator Conroy in his contribution on the second reading went to this very issue. If tax avoiders—that is, people who are wealthy—have income which enables them to retain legal and accountancy advice to minimise their tax payments and arrange their affairs so as to avoid taxation, and thus escape the tax obligations that ordinary citizens feel and are obliged to meet, it does not mean that there is a gap: someone else meets it. Those people who cannot necessarily afford all the advantages of a well-incomed person—people on low incomes—end up meeting it. Tax avoidance usually favours the wealthy and imposes a penalty on low income people—on the poor.

I am advised that bringing forward the operational date to 1 October 1997, which is more than two years after it was announced that this measure should be introduced, would mean that the revenue would forgo $400 million. That is a substantial amount. I do not know whether the government will confirm it, but that is my advice. I think it is good advice and I think that that is a reasonable ballpark figure. That is $400 million that people who are wealthy enough to form trusts can avoid, but people on pay-as-you-earn incomes—people who pay tax because it is taken out of their income every week, fortnight or month according to how they are paid—cannot avoid it.

Those people will pay the end bill of $400 million because the government will end up raising the amount of revenue that it wants. I do not think that is a fair thing to do, and the interests of low paid people have to be considered when the interests of all people are being considered in this. Everyone has been on notice since May 1995, so it is not as though they did not know that this legislation was coming. Certainly, they might be a bit surprised about how slow this government was in bringing it forward, but they did know that it was coming. For that reason, I do not think this amendment should succeed.

The two issues that I have dealt with do not quite go to one of the points raised by Senator Margetts when, in supporting this amendment, she made an observation about the lack of voices on the government benches opposed to retrospectivity. I have heard that argument too. I know who the advocates of it are. For the record, I just want to say that retrospective application of the law is, as a principle, unjust. People do things which are legal, and to have them subsequently declared illegal and have the law reach back in time and penalise them for what they did is unjust. That is a well-known principle.

However, there is an exception in the case of tax avoidance, and I think it is an appropriate one. Where people manage to evade tax in such a way that their fellow taxpayers have to bear the burden of that evasion, and they do it in a way that was never intended—they find a loophole, contort the technicalities, manipulate the act to artificially find a way through that you could say was legal but which was never intended and which is against what the popular understanding of appropriate behaviour was—in those circumstances governments should always be ready to legislate retrospectively and to wipe out those gains. That would kill off the tax avoidance industry. If they knew a government was prepared to wipe out the ill-gotten gains of tax avoidance, then there would be no profit in being a tax avoider. In those circumstances, there is a case for retrospective legislation.

talk.start.para: —I ought to correct some of the statements that have just been made by Senator Cook. I clearly stated that the Greens (WA) did not have a problem with retrospectively looking at those people, and we know there have been people—and for some reason the Australian Taxation Office has avoided prosecuting them for trading in tax losses—who have been advised by government departments and entities to structure their businesses as trusts over time, and had done it not as a means of rorting the system but as a means of legitimate carryover of losses for the benefit of utilising at some stage when they do gain an income. I do not think they are the people that Senator Cook was describing.

speech.para: We have never stood up here on the principle that those people who have rorted the system should be able to get away with it. What we have said all along about this legislation is that it is not designed to particularly target those people who have rorted the system. It seems to be getting at the wrong people. This retrospectivity is likely to cast a wide net and it seems to be a fairly blatant revenue grab. That is what I am saying. It is not about those people who have misused the system; it is about those people who have legitimate reasons. I would think the majority of the people who will be losing money in this particular revenue grab will have done so for legitimate reasons.

talk.start.para: —Senator Kemp has not had a chance yet to confirm the question that Senator Cook asked. I ask whether Senator Murray has any estimate of the revenue that this amendment would forgo. Senator Margetts, I think you have been sold a pup. If there is no change—and this came out in the committee hearings—in the underlying ownership of the trust they can still carry the losses forward. That is the key test. If they incurred the economic loss, they can still carry it forward. The only trick to this is if they try to sell it off or change their structure and be something else, or owned partially or differently, then they cannot carry it forward because the new body in actual fact did not incur the economic loss. So I put it very strongly: you have been sold a pup on the way this legislation will impact upon these arrangements.

speech.para: I am also concerned about the distress that Senator Murray seemed to find at the committee hearings, the distress from the battlers of Brighton—all those multicultural people that Senator Murray is so concerned about who live in Brighton and put in submissions to the committee. Those same people told us they had never seen anybody or knew of anybody trafficking in trust losses or even noticed any trafficking in trust losses. They had failed to notice the ads in the newspapers that became so blatant that they said, `Here we have some trust losses to sell. Come and buy a trust loss off us.'

Nobody who appeared before the committee had noticed or knew anybody who noticed or participated in trafficking in trust losses. So those same people want to come forward and talk about the distress, which Senator Murray claims he detected. I have to say that I had some trouble believing that they were suffering significant distress. I understand that they are upset about the possibility of losing $300 million worth of revenue over the last three years that the government will pick up.

But I want to come back to a couple of points I made earlier. I refer to Senator Murray's minority report where he talks about trusts and launches into quite a lengthy defence of the poor, innocent, much maligned family trust. He quotes from the eminent economist Professor John Quiggin, who says:

There are almost no trusts in Australia established for legitimate purposes . . . The vast majority of trusts are set up with the primary purpose of avoiding tax that should be paid by high-income earners, thereby transferring the burden onto the rest of us. It is these trusts that are typically referred to as `legitimate family trusts'.

It worries me that you have this perception of legitimate family trusts. A quote I read earlier and contained in Senator Murray's report is from Robert Gottliebsen where he basically describes `income-splitting trusts' as `the cornerstone of the structure of a large number of the country's very small businesses'. That is what they are for. They are designed to exploit the tax-free threshold. What I mean by `exploit' is that you share around the $5,400 among your two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, 10 people, and if Senator Murray had his way earlier we would have about 20 people sharing $5,400.

The way it works is that you are able to pass the income through the different people, lowering everybody's individual rate. I am not sure if you were in the chamber when I spoke earlier, Senator Margetts, but some examples have been in newspapers, freely available, in articles by George Megalogenis and Phillip Hudson.

For example, a PAYE person who earns $50,000 would pay $14,000 in tax but a two-beneficiary trust would pay $9,000. A $100,000 with four beneficiaries—these are not big amounts of money; these are what you would possibly perceive as legitimate family trusts—would pay only $18,000 in tax compared to a PAYE of $37,000. That is half the legitimate amount of tax. The income that the entity has generated is just split up. I have not heard Senator Murray address this issue at all. If he wants to defend legitimate family trusts then the Democrats' position is to stand up and explain that the cornerstone of a family trust is about effectively tax planning the $5,400 tax-free threshold. That is it.

It is nothing more exciting than that. It is just the ability to play around with as many tax free thresholds as you can lump into your trust. George Megalogenis says that for a breadwinner and a PAYE taxpayer who earns $200,000, the effective tax rate, with the Medicare levy, is 44 per cent. If he or she is lucky enough to have a legitimate family trust of four—that is, a breadwinner, a spouse of either sex and children—they are able to minimise their effective tax rate to just under 30 per cent.

That is what it is about. It is not about retrospectivity. It is not about whether or not there was distress at the committee. The cornerstone of this debate is whether the public revenue loss that has been going on and growing is due to more and more people taking advantage of effective tax planning, effective tax minimisation—all of which is completely legal. Senator Murray and the Democrats talk about this in their minority report. At page 20 of the report, the first page of Senator Murray's minority report, it states:
. . . trusts may be used to maximise tax effectiveness and tax planning in ways which are not available to incorporated bodies.
Senator Murray states it in black and white. `Maximise tax effectiveness' is accountants' code for tax avoidance. It is perfectly legal but that is what it means.

I am worried that Senator Margetts has been sold a pup, as I have said a couple of times, and she has the perception that we are bashing legitimate family trusts and that the government is attacking legitimate family trusts. The key point is that if there is no change in the underlying ownership, if the same people are continuing to trade in the same way under this legislation, they can carry forward their loss. It is only if they try to sell off their loss and change their structure that they are going to be caught by this legislation.

talk.start.para: —Senator Conroy may remember that during my speech in the second reading debate, or perhaps he was not listening to my speech, I said that we thought it was odd that the family trust should have been picked out by the government as being exempt from this legislation. I would be very happy to hear whether or not the Labor Party is suggesting that, should they get back into power, they would deal with family trusts and remove what is now an anomaly to the situation.

—Senator Cook put his argument with his normal lucidity, but we disagree this time. As you know, we have worked on a number of committees together and we have been pursuing this matter of trusts for some time. I may have missed it, because I did not read all the Hansard from the House of Representatives, but I think it would be helpful for you to say whether you are in fact changing Labor policy to outlaw trusts altogether. Alternatively, which is a legitimate construction put upon the remarks you made earlier, I would have been surprised if you did not move an amendment to excise government exemptions for family trusts. I do not know whether what I am hearing is a personal message or is Labor Party policy. I would have thought that if that is how Labor felt then that is the amendment they should have moved and which we would have considered.

speech.para: I now turn to the question on which we disagree, Senator Cook. You would be aware that I do the best I can in committee to understand the proceedings and to arrive at a considered conclusion. Quite often we have had the same conclusion and a number of times we have not—it depends on the committee. The problem that the coalition, the Labor Party and the Democrats face is that neither the ATO nor the various professionals who deal with these things or any other person at the hearing could fully outline the consequences of the legislation that is before us.

If there is one thing we are all in agreement on in this chamber it is that the legislation before us is different to that which was put up by Labor. The point that they made quite clearly and which we have taken up and with which we disagree, concerns the consequence that people who legitimately lay off losses against profits, as is normal in any business activity, are going to be prejudiced. Amongst those people prejudiced are quite a range of people who do not number amongst the so-called very wealthy.

Neither I nor, I suspect, anyone else can tell you the extent of that problem because none of the expert witnesses could—and they are more expert in these matters than probably anyone here, possibly with the exception of someone like Senator Watson who is pretty cluey on this stuff.

talk.start.para: —He's not here.

—No, he is not here. That was the problem we faced. We were informed in our opinion by Labor's Senator Cooney who chairs the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and brought down a report saying, `This thing has a retrospective problem.'

speech.para: We felt this was the correct principle to deal with that. In our report we deliberately drew attention to the problems that exist with trusts. Most fundamentally, under neither the Labor government nor the coalition government has there been a proper analysis of trusts. The very questions I asked elicited for the first time some understanding of their profile.

Frankly, none of us, Democrats included, know the detail of how trusts look. It is far too easy, far too simple and far too prejudicial to automatically wipe them off. It is the same kind of language if you say that all unions are bad or all trusts are bad. Yes, some are bad, but some others are not. We have to be careful of that. I deliberately quoted Professor John Quiggin because he is very hard on trusts. I did not put that in my report by accident. He said that there are almost no trusts in Australia established for legitimate purposes. What I want to know is what informed him to that opinion. What research has been done? There is none available in a broad, analytical, credible sense. I said in the second reading debate that we are more than happy for the government to change direction—but they should change direction not retrospectively but prospectively because that is how you change policy.
We then go beyond the question of numbers of trusts to the instances of trafficking in trusts. The report states:
Senator Murray —If there were 360,000 trusts, how many advertisements would have appeared in the year in Melbourne and Sydney? One per cent would be 3,600. Would there have been 3,600 advertisements?
Mr Warnock, legal counsel for the National Tax and Accountants Association—I would classify him as an expert witness; I have no reason not to—said:
Certainly not. At the time there would have been very few advertisements—
Senator Murray —Three hundred and thirty six advertisements? Thirty six?

Mr Warnock —No, I would say the advertisements for trust losses would have been under 10 . . . In my experience, when it was around, it was more that everybody heard about it, not many people had an actual involvement in it.

Either somebody in this Senate is calling this person a liar or is saying that he is mistaken, but that to me means that advertisements were not a major way in which trafficking in trust losses occurred.

I am quite happy to concede that it may have been done by word of mouth. There may have been other ways of doing it. I am quite happy to concede that the numbers are not known to me and, I suggest, are not known to anyone, including the ATO. But the fact is that the expert witness said that the total number of advertisements was under 10. But every expert witness also said that trafficking in trust losses—and the ATO agreed—ended on 9 May 1995 when Treasurer Willis quite rightly took the steps he did. The Australian Democrats have absolutely no problem with the government seeking to change the direction and nature of tax policy as to how it deals with trusts. That is its prerogative as a government. We have no problem with the ALP wishing to wipe out trusts. That is its prerogative in terms of policy, but we should not confuse it with this issue.

The issue that we put simply was that, firstly, as Labor has agreed, the law that the government intended is quite different to the law that has arrived. Secondly, the trafficking in trust losses, and I do not know if you agree, ended on 9 May 1995. Thirdly, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee said that there was a retrospective problem. Fourthly, the profession as a whole maintained that they were not aware of the full impact of how the trust loss legislation was to run until 17 October 1997.

That is what informs our position. I am content, Senator Cook, that you disagree with it. I do not resent that, but I do not wish to have my or my party's motives impugned. As you know, we have pursued retrospectivity as an issue countless times on different matters. Sometimes you agreed with us and sometimes you did not. This is another one of those occasions. I should also indicate that, because this is a sensitive area, in terms of my own declaration, the trust of which I am a trustee has no trust losses. My own personal pocket is not benefited from this. I know that I do not have the numbers here, but I appreciate the opportunity to put my case.

talk.start.para: —I am concerned that the Democrats position appears to be to try to muddy the waters as much as they can on this issue. Continuing to talk about what trusts look like is not addressing how they operate. The driving mechanism behind a family trust or most of the other trusts is purely and simply the capacity to minimise tax. One commentator recently suggested that the simplest way to fix family trusts is not to ban them or outlaw them but to take away the tax-free threshold and see how attractive the family tax structure is after you take away the tax-free threshold.

speech.para: I am not advocating that. I am just reporting that that is what one commentator has suggested. That commentator said that he believed that it would quickly dry up. People would lose interest in the family trust. Let us see if all those other wonderful things that Senator Murray talks about in the minority report—the beneficial and ultimate control of a trust is shielded from public disclosure; the distribution of income in a trust is generally discretionary and can vary between the beneficiaries year by year; and the beneficiaries of trusts are shielded from the public eye—survive if the tax-free threshold of $5,400 is removed as an option across the board. Let us see where the economic incentive to set up a family trust comes. Senator Margetts, these are just these legitimate family trusts that Senator Murray is so fond of describing.

I do not have the confidence that Senator Murray has in the evidence that was given to the committee about how trust losses ended in 1995. No-one who came before the committee had ever been party to one of them. Given they knew nothing about them before they came before the committee and had not noticed them, how the hell would they know if they had stopped? How on earth could they sit there and say, `It's all stopped. We didn't know it was happening before but it's definitely stopped now'? How on earth can you take that evidence on face value?

But the really worrying part of your amendment, Senator Murray, is that, even if it did stop in 1995, you are proposing to open it up again for 2½ to three years. Let them go off and sell $400 million worth of trust losses because that is the forgone revenue. Let them go and do it. It was wrong. Everybody who came before the committee was wrong.

No-one wants to defend trafficking trust losses, but you want those people who are unscrupulous enough to do it to have a window of opportunity to take $400 million out of the public purse, to allow the government to pretend how unfair the tax system is, how we have to have a GST to fix it, and to see all these people avoiding tax. You want to open up that window for them, and that really concerns me on traditional Democrat philosophy. Why on earth would you want to open up that window? I would be interested if Senator Murray wanted to contribute further.

talk.start.para: —Simply put, it is not our view that it would open up to $400 million worth of loss. As I clearly outlined at length in the second reading debate, we dispute these figures put before us by the ATO. I do not know how valid or not valid they are from Senator Conroy. To me, quite frankly, it is not that relevant. We are going to go down with this.

speech.para: The second point made was that this opens up a window for trafficking in trust losses. It does not. It deals only with trust losses which, as with company losses, personal losses or partnership losses, are legitimate ways of dealing with expenditure. I do not believe we should prolong this anymore. We are not going to agree. I have answered you as best I can.

talk.start.para: —Through you, Madam Temporary Chairman, I would still be interested in your contribution, Senator Murray, notwithstanding the fact that neither of us really wants to spend all night here arguing about this. If there is no change in the underlying ownership, the losses can still be carried forward. There was no disagreement about that at the committee. I know you have many committees to attend.
—Senator Conroy, if you are directing your comments through me, you do not actually then direct them to Senator Murray.

—Thank you, Madam Temporary Chairman. No-one at the committee disagreed that you could carry forward the tax losses if there was no change in the underlying ownership. So any legitimate activity on your definition of legitimate—and I have clearly raised concerns—
—Through me.
—Can I just clarify with the chair, does that mean I have to face you at all time?
—No, but you do not then refer to Senator Murray.
—I did not think I did. I will check the Hansard .
—Yes, you did.

—I apologise if I did. Nobody disputed that issue. No-one disputed that you could carry forward the tax losses under this existing regime. As long as you incur that economic loss, you can still use that economic loss. As I said, Senator Murray may not want to further join the debate, but I invite other senators, if they want to respond, to respond.

—Just briefly, I have deliberately not indulged in the larger discussion or philosophy at stake here because I want to deal solely with retrospectivity. But the point has been made that losses incurred legitimately where ownership does not change will still be intact. In that case, how on earth do you arrive at $400 million? We can throw hundreds of millions around as we see fit, but I just do not accept that the consequence of the amendment is as you have suggested. But, frankly, there is no way here that either you or I can prove it. We will end up saying, through the chair, `I said and she said,' `You said and he said,' and we will not get anywhere. So I will end my remarks there.

—The difference in the concern of the other senators was the start-up date. The projections are $90 million in 1995-96, $185 million in 1996-97 and somewhere in the $160 million region for some of this year, depending on the start-up date and implementation. You are giving that away if you accept the Democrat amendment.

speech.para: While there is no question that you can always argue about an exact figure on these sorts of estimates, to turn around and take a position where you say, `We're not sure what the exact amount is, so we'll give the lot away,' is a brave leap. It is a brave leap by the Democrats that the Labor Party and, I believe, the government do not want to share. But to say that just because it may be only $85 million, instead of the $90 million or $95 million that the tax office has said, is no substantive reason to say, `Let's give it away by changing the start-up date by the best part of two to three years.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be able to join this debate. I have listened with great interest to Senator Murray and Senator Conroy on this issue, and I would like to make a number of comments and observations. There were a couple of questions which were asked of me to which I will respond. I might say, however, Senator Conroy, there were a couple of questions asked of you by Senator Murray and Senator Margetts to which you did not respond.

speech.para: Senator Cook interjecting—

talk.start.para: —No, it was very interesting because we were listening with great interest to see what the Labor Party attitude was to family trusts, whether the Labor Party policy was to in some way remove concessions to family trusts or whether the Labor Party was proposing some other measures. We shall read your comments in the Hansard with great interest.
—I am a humble backbencher.
—The old backdown. Can't you pick it? You are not a humble backbencher; you are one of the Labor Party warlords in Victoria. We all know that.
—Senator Kemp, direct your comments through the chair.

—Thank you, Madam Temporary Chairman. I was being provoked. I think Senator Conroy undervalues himself. He is one of the Labor Party warlords in Victoria and what he says counts, certainly in Labor Party circles in my state. Senator Conroy, I think people will read what you said with a great deal of interest.

speech.para: We did note that Senator Murray and Senator Margetts asked good questions. Senator Murray, you said all these things. You said that you do not like family trusts. You explained about the threshold, and then you asked what the Labor Party policy is. Did you note, Senator Murray—through you, Madam Temporary Chairman—how it all suddenly went dead? I thought it was a good question, Senator Murray. I do not always praise you in this chamber, it has to be said, but I thought it was a good question. We will look very closely at what Senator Cook said because people will want to know what the taxation policy of the Labor Party is and we are having some difficulties ascertaining what directions the Labor Party are heading in.

The second point I make in relation to the comments that Labor senators made is that you have to come to these debates on tax avoidance with clean hands. It is no good suddenly getting up in this chamber and lecturing the government of the day when we can look back over 13 years of Labor government. It is simply not good enough to come in and pretend suddenly that the Labor Party is determined to crack down on tax avoidance with very aggressive tax planning arrangements. The truth of the matter is that every time a bill comes before this chamber—with few exceptions—the Labor Party goes missing in action. When we talk in this chamber of Senator R&D syndicates, we all know who we are talking about.

talk.start.para: —That was Ron Boswell, wasn't it?

—No, it was not. In that case, with the exception of Senator Margetts, we all know who we are talking about. Peter Cook unashamedly led a major defence of a major loophole in R&D syndicates. Equally, when we tried to do something in relation to improving the equity of superannuation, Senator Sherry and Senator Cook led a major attack on that measure. So I have to tell you that the Labor Party do not come with clean hands to this debate. If they were so worried about trust losses and trafficking in trust losses, they sure took a long time to bring in the legislation. They had been in government for well over a decade.

speech.para: As I said, I think we are entitled to judge the Labor Party not only by their words but by their history and it is a history which in my view is very grubby in this area, so I would appreciate it if Labor senators did not get up and pretend to lecture the government. The government moves with great vigour in areas of tax avoidance. Every time you get up and raise these issues, we will respond and we will remind the public of exactly what your miserable record is.

In response to the question by Senator Cook about the cost of acceding to Senator Murray's amendment, we have not got precise figures, as you would expect, but it could be expected to cost hundreds of millions of dollars. The issue was raised about whether trafficking in trust losses occurred after the announcement on 9 May 1995. The Australian Taxation Office, for example, is aware of one case involving the sale in 1996 of trust losses with millions upon millions of dollars of losses. So trafficking has occurred after the announcement of the commencement date. That is the advice we have received.

I think Senator Margetts became very confused between grandfathering and retrospectivity. I think the Hansard will show when we read your remarks that you slid very easily between grandfathering and retrospectivity. The government simply does not accept that this is a retrospective bill. It does not accept that argument. The measures were announced by the former government on 9 May 1995 and this government has consistently advised taxpayers that the measures will apply from 9 May 1995. There is a clear record that the coalition made that commitment after the Labor Party brought in the original bill. It has been well known that we do not accept the argument that Senator Margetts was running that this is retrospectivity. The taxpayers have had the benefit of the draft legislation since September 1995. You raise your eyebrows, Senator Margetts, but they have. Changing the commencement date in our view would allow those involved in tax avoidance to benefit at the expense of those who have heeded the government's announcements about trust losses. I would point out that any changes that have been made to the measures announced in the original bill that are detrimental to taxpayers have a prospective commencement date. I do not think that point has been made in the debate and it is worth recording.

In relation to the grandfathering of the pre 9 May 1995 losses, I make the following points. The trust loss measures are designed to prevent the transfer of the tax benefit of trust losses to those who did not economically suffer them, and Senator Conroy made that point at least 40 times I think. It was a good point and, if you had avoided repeating it tirelessly, we would have appreciated it even more, but it was a good point. A major purpose of the measures was to stop the transfers of the tax benefit of trust losses that were occurring prior to 9 May 1995.

I make this point, Madam Temporary Chair, that if the legislation does not apply to losses incurred prior to 9 May 1995, a taxpayer deriving assessable income after 9 May 1995 that should be exposed to tax could shelter that income from tax using a trust loss, even though they did not suffer it. This would be unfair to ordinary taxpayers who do not derive the kind of income that can be sheltered from tax using trust losses. Most of the revenue estimates are based on stopping transfers of the tax benefit of these losses. However, a trust—and I think Senator Conroy made this point many times, not quite 40 but it was a good point and Senator Conroy does like to repeat himself—will only be prevented from deducting losses if something happens after the commencement date that demon strates that the tax benefit of those losses has been transferred. I think that was a point that was well made. I do not use Senator Conroy's exact words; I use the more technical words that have been given to me by my tax advisers, but that is the case and it is essentially the same thing.

The advice I have received, Senator Murray, is that the amendment is technically deficient for the following reasons: the amendment directly conflicts with other provisions in the bill; it may allow the use of deductions by a trust that would otherwise be disallowed under the existing provisions of the law; it is unclear how the portion of the loss for the 1994-95 income tax year incurred before 9 May 1995 would be calculated given that tax losses are normally worked out on a whole of income year basis; the amendment refers to losses being declared in a trust's taxation return for the 1994-95 income year—until recently trust returns did not provide for losses to be separately listed and losses for income years before 1994-95 would not be declared in the 1994-95 tax return; and, finally, it is unclear whether the amendment would apply to debt deductions and quarantined foreign losses, which were also dealt with by the bill. I conclude my remarks by indicating that the government will not be supporting the amendments which have been moved by Senator Murray.

talk.start.para: —I am fascinated by the example given by the minister in relation to millions and millions of dollars rorted through trafficking of trust losses. If there was an example—or was it more than one—of millions and millions of dollars being trafficked or rorted through the tax system, can I please ask: has this ever been legal in the last few years, to rort the tax system through trafficking in tax losses? If it has not, what has happened? In that particular example, or those particular examples, were those people prosecuted and, if not, why not?

—Senator, have you been around? We are trying to change the law. Don't you understand that what we are trying to do, with this bill, is to prevent these things happening? You, with your amendment, are trying to allow them to happen. What we are trying to do is to prevent those losses being used as deductions. We can speed the journey, and if you are prepared to vote for this bill we can clear this matter up very quickly.

speech.para: I was quoting an example because I think the point was made about whether there had been any trafficking in trust losses since the original bill was brought in in May 1995. I looked to my advisers and they gave me an example, one which was a particularly extensive example, which I quoted for the information of the chamber. I was responding to a question and I thought that that was an appropriate thing to do. But, Senator, the point that is we are trying to make a law to prevent trafficking in trust losses and that is what this whole debate is about.

talk.start.para: —Quite a number of the distressed battlers from Brighton who came before the committee made the point, through you, Madam Temporary Chairman—
—It is through me, but you then speak about other senators in the third person. You will get yourself into a lot less trouble if you do that.

—Through you, the evidence that came before us was that part 4A could be applied now, and why wasn't it being applied? I would not want for a moment to be wanting to be defending Senator Kemp but we, as did the previous Labor government, lost confidence that part 4A could deal with this, which is why we introduced the original bill. I think it is a question of part 4A being very general, and this is very specific. It was possible that we would have spent a number of years in the courts and in the end been unsuccessful and had to come back to this anyway. The short answer, to assist the minister, is that part 4A, on reasonable advice, may not have been successful.

—If I may say so, Senator Margetts, you seemed to be bowling along at a great rate and, of course, it could only be done on a case by case basis, which is an important point to make. No one was treating you, Senator, as a fool. No-one would do that in this chamber. But you did ask a question: why don't we prosecute? The advice is we had to have appropriate legislation to deal with the problem, and that is what we are doing.

—I just want to point out something for the record. I do know the difference between grandfathering and retrospectivity, but I do not think the minister does, and I think a lot of his front and backbenchers do know the difference, and that is why they are not in the chamber tonight.

—I want to make two relatively brief points to clear up any misunderstandings in the Senate. In a number of the contributions under this amendment there have been questions about what is Labor Party policy and the minister has made—shall I say, to be fair to him—some snide observations about Labor Party policy.

speech.para: Labor Party policy on tax, at least on trusts, was last enunciated by Treasurer Ralph Willis when he brought down the changes in this area. That is Labor Party policy. That is where we stand. There is no ambiguity about that and there should be no mystery about that. I can tell you something else for nothing. Labor Party policy on tax is no GST, and we would not support a GST either.

As far as the rest of our tax package is concerned, we are engaged in a process of actually conducting a reform of the tax system and we will announce quite far reaching tax reform at an appropriate time. I might say, it would help the debate in Australia if the government, which has access to the Treasury and which, at taxpayers' expense, has set up a secret inquiry to examine tax options, at least gave the public the benefit of the work of that inquiry so that Australian citizens could decide for themselves, based on impartial Treasury knowledge, what the best options were. It is a pity as well that the government has directed the affairs of that inquiry so as to require it to study only options which involve a GST.

What we have as far as so-called tax reform is concerned—and `reform' is the most abused word I have recently heard in English—is a secret process being conducted by the government, none of which will be made available to the community. At the end of the day, the electors of this country will be ambushed at the eleventh hour with a package, on a take it or leave it basis, which will be a marketing package. The implications of it—the details, the hidden nasties—will not be available for public scrutiny until it is too late. That is not a process of government that at all commends itself to the Labor Party.

What did we do when we were in office? First of all, we inherited a ramshackle tax system. Tonight we have had from Senator Kemp what he regards as some of the `imperfections' of the Labor Party on tax. Let me tell the Senate that, when we came to office in 1983, leading tax academics in this country were saying that with the bottom of the harbour schemes and with the ramshackle tax system that Australia had, for the wealthy the payment of tax was optional. You could drive a coach-and-four through clauses in the tax act. That was what the now Prime Minister, the then Treasurer John Howard, bequeathed to Australia in 1983. That is what we addressed with a national tax summit in 1985. On the question of tax purity, let us get the record clear again. Who opposed the reform measures then?

talk.start.para: —Bill Kelty.
—No. The reform measures then were opposed by the then opposition. I am not sure whether, through you Madam Temporary Chairman, Senator Kemp was a member of this chamber at that stage.
—Thank you, Senator Cook.

—Certainly his party—the Liberal Party, the coalition—opposed us every inch of the way on capital gains tax, most of the way on fringe benefits tax and on all those things that brought a degree of equity and fairness to the tax system. That is what you opposed us on. So when you say `lecture us', do not come in here and lecture the Labor Party on tax fairness. The principles that we tried to enshrine in the tax act in 1985 were the principles of efficiency, simplicity and equity.
—Why did you so comprehensively fail?

—I take the interjection, `Why did we so comprehensively fail?' The last major reform of the tax system in Australia was conducted by us. As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, from time to time the tax system needs efficient repair and sometimes renovation. It needs it because every time you divide the law, those in the tax avoidance industry, which is a major industry in this country, spend their best efforts to find a way around the law and occasionally they succeed. Governments should always be adept at blocking off those loopholes. Therefore, you should repair the system and after a while you are required to renovate the system.

speech.para: I also remind the Senate that a GST is a regressive tax. It applies the same amount of tax irrespective of your income. A pensioner and a millionaire pay the same amount of tax. That is a regressive tax. That is not what the Labor Party supports; that is what the government supports. That is what they call tax reform; that is not what we call tax reform. If you are going to fight an election, as you keep saying to us you will, let us do it fairly.

In 1985, we published a series of papers—option A, option B and option C. Option C had a GST in it; the other options did not. We engaged in a national debate about tax reform. The country had reference to authoritative Treasury documents, impartially calculated tables and the opinions of leading tax officers in this country. It was all out there in the public for debate. We had a proper debate about it. We won the election, we had a summit, we made a decision at that summit and we reformed the tax act.

What do we have now? We have a secret committee with no records, no minutes and no outcomes, as far as we know, at this stage. We have a promise that on trusts there would have been a paper presented for the public to look out. That is now a broken promise. We are not going to see that paper. We are going to see the final recommendations that the government makes.

Are we going to see the options from this committee? No. Are we going to see the calculations of Treasury produced for this committee? No. Are we going to see how it impacts on the lower paid and what the level of the tax is, what the exemptions might be? No we are not. We have a tax debate in secret, and a tax debate by PR—by manipulating headlines. That is not democracy. There is a name for that sort of behaviour. We have seen it in other countries before. It certainly ain't democracy.

I just say this for the record, Minister, since you are so fond of raising this matter. It may be that you will put your proposals to the people of Australia at a time to suit your convenience—more like at a time to ambush them. It may be that you are able to put a momentary gloss on those proposals to make them interesting and attractive. It may be that you will use the tax system to buy votes by giving tax cuts at particular strategic levels of the tax system to attract votes at that level irrespective of the impact at other levels of income. It may be that you will do all those things.

talk.start.para: —You are backsliding, Senator. You are still referring to Senator Kemp directly. Could you try to direct your comments through the chair.
—I was under the impression I was, Madam Chairman, but if you say I wasn't then clearly I wasn't, and I now shall.
—You were doing well earlier but you have slipped.
—Thank you for bringing my attention to it. I do appreciate your assistance, Madam Chairman.

speech.para: I conclude on this point. You will not win this debate. You might win it for a small time but you will not win it overall, because Australians in 1985 rejected the idea of a GST and at the election in 1993 they rejected it again. All of the surveys of popular opinion show disapproval for it now in the majority.

There is no way in which you can compromise between your objectives of a GST and proper and fair remuneration for those at the lower income levels, and there is no way you can bring in a GST which will not increase over time. Every other one has; there is no reason to expect yours will not. And there is no reason to believe that in the end there will be anything like an attack on the black economy, because in the countries of the world where there is a GST the black economy thrives—but only in a different form, not in the form we know it. So when we talk about tax reform let us bear those things in mind.

My concluding remark on this point is that one of the things you criticise us for is our supporting a process of tax breaks for research and development. Well, all those Australian scientists who stand on the dock and watch their ideas go overseas and be commercialised by someone else thank you. They thank you. And those people who would have had jobs in Australia making sophisticated scientific and technological equipment based on those scientific ideas but are now unemployed also thank you. So let us not have any of this cant about that.

I do not mind participating in a debate in this chamber in a robust way and I like to deal with people fairly. And I am troubled by Senator Murray in the sense that he seemed to think that I was trying to impute motive to him—

talk.start.para: —Not true, Senator.

—No, well, I wasn't. I do disagree with you, Senator, and vigorously so. And I will vote against your proposition—not in the sense of imputing ill-conceived or bad motives to you; simply because I disagree with you. And I think that is the view on our side entirely. In that sense I do disagree but I do not question motive.

—I want to make one final contribution to this debate. I am still concerned at some of the issues that have been raised in the debate so far this evening. I am disappointed in the Democrats' position that they just want to talk on retrospectivity, because I think the Democrats in their minority report mounted quite a strong case about the legitimate family trust. Particularly for the Greens, I want to refer to a recently released tax office report on the compliance costs and legitimate family tax trusts.
—Is this about the same pup?
—Yes, I think it is that pup again. I am quoting again from an article by George Megalogenis:

speech.para: The second headache for Howard arising from the ATO report was the evidence that a huge slice of the present tax compliance costs suffered by small business was self-inflicted.
The report revealed that small businesses run through a trust structure faced double the tax compliance costs of those run as a sole trader, partnership or company.

The results shocked the ATO, which thought the red tape costs of a trust and company would be similar. The only conclusion that can be drawn is that small businesses using trusts are spending a lot of extra money on lawyers and accountants to get around the tax laws.

That comes back to the point I made earlier: take away the tax threshold—they are paying more money. They are complaining about red tape and how much it costs to comply, and yet they are willing to spend more money of their own hard-earned income to set up these trusts. I know this is going to be an ongoing debate in the chamber and in the country over the next six months with the tax reform debate, so I say, particularly to the Greens, that it is very important that we analyse what the economic benefit of the legitimate family trust is. The Democrats do not seem to want to enter into that debate today, and that is their position. I look forward to ongoing debate with the Democrats on that issue—and I am sure there will be. But, particularly for the Greens, we are back to that pup, that question of what is legitimate. If you examine the economic benefit received, the fact that they are prepared to pay more to be in them, you have to begin to start worrying about why they are so determined to protect their position at the expense of the ordinary taxpayer who does not have the capacity to get into a family trust.

I make a final point. Trusts have exploded in the last few years. Trafficking exploded in the last few years in the trust losses. The government wants to make a big thing of asking, `Why didn't you do anything for 13 years?' The answer is that in the last few years it became a major drain and it will become an enormous future drain. speech.para: (3) Schedule 1, page 137 (after line 25), after item 24, insert:

para.inline: 24A Transitional—unit trusts and schemes to take advantage of deductions

speech.para: (1) This item modifies the effect of Division 270 of the trust loss etc. Schedule where the trust mentioned in paragraph 270-10(1)(a) of that Schedule is a unit trust (regardless of whether the unit trust is a fixed trust or a non-fixed trust) and the units are held by 2 or more unrelated persons.
(2) If a scheme in respect of a unit trust meets the following conditions, it is deemed to be a scheme which is exempt from the consequences set out in section 270-15:
(a) a unit trust has incurred losses before 1995 Budget time which have been declared in the trust's taxation return for the 1994-95 year of income; and
(b) a unit holder's family trust has made a distribution of income in favour of the unit trust (the nominated distribution); and
(c) the unit holder makes an election to seek exemption from the income injection test in Division 270 in respect of the nominated distribution; and
(d) the unit-holder making the election is a family member or is included in the family group of the family trust which makes the nominated distribution; and

(e) the total of all nominated distributions specified in elections made by a unit-holder does not exceed a proportion of all losses available for carry forward by the unit trust at 1995 Budget time, which have not otherwise been recouped, the proportion being equal to the proportion of the units in the unit trust owned by the unit-holder; and
(f) an election mentioned in paragraph (c) is made by the unit-holder with the consent of all unit-holders; and
(g) the unit-holder making the election was a unit-holder at the time the unit trust incurred the loss; and
(h) the unit trust meets all other relevant tests prescribed in this Act.

Minister, as you clearly picked up in your earlier remarks, this is a horrendously complex bill and it is difficult to amend. I appreciate your forbearance as we have gone through the debate. This amendment relates to joint venture unit trusts and schemes and refers to transitional arrangements. It extends the transitional provisions to ensure that unrelated unit holders and unit trusts, currently denied the family amendment concessions, are not denied the tax benefits resulting from legitimate carried forward losses at 9 May 1995. Such provisions will restrict the benefit allowed to no greater than the proportion of all losses available for carry forward by the trust as at 9 May 1995, which is equal to the proportion of the units in the unit trust owned by the unit holder. Secondly, it will ensure that only those who are unit holders at the time the loss was incurred are allowed this proportionate benefit.

A transitional measure relating to unit trusts with trust losses is necessary because the facility for placing trusts within family groups for the purposes of the income injection test, as announced by the Treasurer on budget night, will not cover cases where business activities are conducted by a unit trust which has incurred losses; where the units are held by two or more unrelated parties except in very limited circumstances; and where all those parties and the unit trust can be constituted as one family group for the purposes of the income injection test.

The proposed transitional measure is designed to overcome this unfair and inequitable state of affairs as follows: each unit holder will be entitled to elect that the unit trust with carry forward losses be exempted from the income injection test to the extent that it would otherwise apply by reason only that if distribution of income is made by the unit holders' family trust in favour of the unit trust, which is the nominated distribution, and the nominated distribution must be specified in the election; the unit holder making the election must be a family member or be included in the family group of the family trust which makes the nominated distribution; the unit-holder may continue to make elections during different years of income, provided that the total of all nominated distributions specified in elections made by a unit-holder shall not exceed a proportion of all losses available for carry forward by the unit trust as at 9 May 1995 and not otherwise recouped, which is equal to the proportion of the units and the unit trust owned by the unit holder.

No elections described in paragraph (a) will be made by any unit holder except with the consent of all unit holders, and the unit holder making the election must have been the unit holder at the time the unit trust originally incurred the losses. If senators are still following me, they are better men than I!

The application of the proposed transitional measure will be restricted to losses incurred as at 9 May 1995. The measure is intended to apply with effect from 9 May 1995 only to unit trusts, irrespective of whether they are technically fixed trusts or non-fixed trusts. The proposed transitional measure will only apply where the unit trust meets all the relevant tests prescribed by the trust losses legislation, other than an income injection test, irrespective of whether unit holders are individuals, fixed trusts, non-fixed trusts, family trust companies, or any combination of the above.

A transitional measure along the lines described above will effectively cure a clear inequity in the design of the proposed trust losses legislation. It is consistent with the concession made by the Treasurer on budget night and should not be capable of being manipulated or abused for tax avoidance purposes.

My apologies to you, Senator Cook.
