talk.start.para: —We are debating the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] . This bill represents attempt No. 2 by this government to try to break yet another election promise. It represents attempt No. 2 by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Peter Reith, to deny a section of the Australian work force a fundamental right: the right to appeal against unfair, harsh or unreasonable dismissal.

speech.para: The government's current unfair dismissal provisions apply to all employers, irrespective of size, but the government now wants to give some employers the power to sack some workers unfairly. Once again in this chamber we have an ideologically conceived piece of government legislation which has no empirical, quantitative or qualitative evidence to support it, nor has it any moral or justifiable grounds for its enactment. As I said in the previous debate on this measure, it is nothing more than a con. It is a con on the small business sector and a con on the broader Australian community.

The government's propaganda machine has been working overtime to try to convince the Senate that this legislation is required to secure jobs. That is not right; it is a con. This legislation will add to what is already a concern amongst Australian workers—the issue of growing job insecurity. This legislation will create a two-tier industrial relations system; a system under which employees will be separated into two groups: one with the right to appeal against unfair dismissal and one without the right. The right to appeal against unfair dismissal is a right which, in a world of increasing job insecurity, is crucial for the protection of workers from the behaviour of unscrupulous employers.

The question needs to be asked: why are we revisiting this legislation? The Senate has already made a determination on this matter. Is it because the government truly and honestly believes that this legislation is important? No, it is not. This government is not, nor will it ever be, altruistic or genuinely concerned about the conditions and rights of average Australian workers. This legislation is here for one purpose and one purpose only: as a trigger for a double dissolution. That is the only reason why it is back here.

The government has carefully crafted a strategy whereby a number of pieces of legislation will be used as double dissolution triggers, and this is one of them. This legislation is being used to divert attention from the real trigger—the Wik legislation. The government hopes that this bill will camouflage its actual objective, which is to implement its Wik legislation unamended, via double dissolution, a plan which has been hatched despite the fact that 90 per cent of the Wik legislation has been returned unamended by the Senate.

We have before us a piece of legislation that is part of that strategy. In itself, this legislation is unfair and unjust—important points which have been ignored by this government in what is a cynical attempt to ensure that its election plans are not derailed. In order to ensure that this election strategy works, the government is happy in the course of it to subvert and sabotage the rights of average Australian workers. More recently, the government has revealed another part of the election strategy: the complete sale of Telstra, with more jobs lost and more job insecurity. Another double dissolution trigger is looming.

Let me say from the outset that the Australian Labor Party opposes this bill. We have opposed it before and we continue to oppose it. I reiterate the view that we stated in the Senate minority report that inquired into this government's first attempt to abrogate responsibility to ensure that workers are protected from unfair dismissal. I will quote from what I believe was an excellent minority report. It says:
We have come to the very firm conclusion the proposal in the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill to exempt small business from the unfair dismissal laws is seriously flawed and cannot be supported.
In our view, there are numerous convincing arguments against the proposal, but in essence they can be grouped into 3 core concerns:
1. The exemption is an explicit breach of the government's pre-election commitments.
2. The exemption is unnecessary.
3. The exemption is unfair.
We held that view then and we continue to adhere strongly to it now.

I would like to remind the Senate of a number of undertakings given by both the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business and the Prime Minister concerning the rights of workers—undertakings that obviously we now know are in fact non-core undertakings or non-core promises. I do so to put on record the utter hypocrisy of this government. First of all, let us hear what the now Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business had to say before the last federal election on ABC Daybreak on 28 February 1996. He said:
Look, our position's very clear. If you've been unfairly dealt with at work, then you should have a right of appeal.
An ambiguity there I would not have thought. That is pretty clear to me. It was certainly clear to him. The Prime Minister stated on the John Laws show on 23 January 1996:
I'm not going to have a law where an unreasonable employer can capriciously sack a decent, hard-working employee.

talk.start.para: —Who said that?
—The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, said that. Again, the Prime Minister on the ABC on 25 January 1996 said:

speech.para: I'm not going to make it open slather. I'm going to replace it—
that is unfair dismissal provisions—
with a law that's fair to both sides so that if you are doing your job properly you can't be capriciously dismissed.

That is what they said before the election. Perhaps the government could save everybody some angst if they indicated from the outset what is in fact a core or non-core promise. I am sure that the Australian people who have suffered from this government's decisions and policy backflips would probably appreciate it. To make this backflip even more questionable, when the unfair dismissal laws were changed over a year ago the government triumphantly heralded what they regarded as a new era with respect to unfair dismissal provisions. The Prime Minister in his 1996 progress report to the people stated:
I am proud to say that the previous government's anti-job unfair dismissal laws have gone. They have been replaced with a simpler, more balanced system that provides a fair go all round.

What is the Prime Minister talking about here? He is talking about the government's own legislation which they are now attempting to amend. I am not sure that those comments were worth making at that point. I go on to Mr Reith, the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, in his speech on the return of the bill from the Senate. He said on 21 November 1996:

We have delivered a workable system for dealing with unfair dismissal . . . and, in doing so, we have expressed an overwhelming community consensus that the previous Brereton system did nothing more than stifle employment growth and create division in the workplace. This was Labor's legacy, and the government has buried it.

That is from the minister himself. I have restated government undertakings to highlight to the chamber that the government clearly did not see an exemption for small business as being necessary. Indeed, it is crystal clear, as I have pointed out, from the statements made by the Prime Minister and the minister that the purported anti-job effect of the previous law had been, as far as this government was concerned, dealt with and fixed. These undertakings show, I believe, the government's duplicity in introducing this measure not once but twice and shows the utter contempt that this government holds for Australian workers and for its own election commitments and core and non-core promises.

What this government is asking us to do by agreeing to amend its own unfair dismissal legislation—I would like to emphasise that point because I think it is a point that has been lost on the government—is to add to what is already a growing problem of job insecurity in the Australian economy. We are being asked to say to workers in the small business sector that we do not believe that they warrant the same level of protection as workers in other areas. So here we have the two-tier industrial relations system.

We are being asked to say to these workers, `If you are harshly, unreasonably or unfairly dismissed, we don't want to know. It is okay to be discriminated against. It is okay to be sacked capriciously. We just don't want to know about it. We are not going to give you recourse to justice in relation to appealing against what may well be harsh and capricious unfair dismissal.' We are being asked to take away the right of appeal against being unfairly dismissed from one huge section of the Australian work force, a highly significant section of the Australian work force. There will be no protection for those workers, no protection whatsoever.

My colleague in the other place Bob McMullan has highlighted a number of cases which show the importance of unfair dismissal legislation, which I will restate for the record in order so that it is reinforced in terms of our opposition here in the Senate again. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —Last week the government announced the winning bids for the Hobart and Launceston airports. The successful bidder in Launceston was Australian Pacific Airports Corporation—a consortium comprising the British airport operator BAA, Axiom, AMP and Utilities Trust of Australia with the Launceston City Council holding an option to acquire 10 per cent. There has been a very strong campaign, as you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, run by the group called Save Our Airport, a group of local businesses aimed at maximising the level of local ownership in the airport in order that northern Tasmania does not lose out from the sale.

speech.para: As with a number of federal issues like the Howard government's outrageous plan for aged care, child care cuts, cuts to other government services and a very high level of unemployment, the member for Bass, Mr Warwick Smith, found himself under attack again from his constituents. His response to this pressure appeared in today's Launceston Examiner. It is up to his usual standard, I am afraid to say.

Mr Smith has announced a plan to develop what he described as a Hong Kong style special economic development zone around the Launceston airport. He suggested the zone could contain special bond stores to encourage trade. He said that a committee could be set up to run the zone. Its members would include the Launceston and Northern Midlands municipalities, the new airport owner and the Commonwealth. Not surprisingly, there was a negative reaction from both councils to the Smith plan.

This is clearly another off the top of the head reaction by a politician who is under siege. For a start, there are no free trade zones in Hong Kong. The whole island has no barriers to trade and does not levy any tariff. If he is referring to the Shenzen free trade zone, which is located near Hong Kong, then he had better find another example upon which to draw. That zone has been successful because factory owners who have set up there have been guaranteed minimal supervision of wages, working conditions and safety.

Mr Smith would have also been wise to look at the history of the economic development zone established in the Northern Territory before he launched his plan for the Launceston airport. The Smith type plan was implemented in Darwin with terrible results. There were many breaches of the basic rights and entitlements of the workers in that zone largely by companies from Hong Kong—the very place upon which Mr Smith has based his plan. Those Hong Kong based clothing and textile companies forced their employees to live in very difficult conditions, underpaid them and failed to pay them on time. It was a disaster in every respect.

There was also a plan for the establishment of special Queensland zones floated in the early 1990s. That was quickly replaced with a state wide strategy which, from memory, was called the state wide manufacturing industry scheme. The Queensland government obviously took the view at the time that all manufacturing industries in that state were worthy of government support, not just a select few behind a barb wire fence.

Mr Smith also failed to consult the Australian constitution which prohibits discrimination against states or parts of states and provides for free interstate trade. If Mr Smith was to give Launceston airport a free trade zone he would be required to ensure that anyone else who wanted one could have one. It also appears that Mr Smith has a fair way to go if he is going to convince the key members of the Howard government to support his plan.
The views of the Treasurer, Mr Costello, were spelt out very clearly in an article in the Australian Financial Review in July last year. Mr Costello is quoted as saying:
If I had my way I would not choose a small area here . . . to enjoy those benefits and a small area there. I would choose as much of the country as possible.
Mr Costello said that the government would not be diverted into `quick fixes' in its management of the economy. For once I agree with Mr Costello.
This idea also received a negative response from Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Mr Moore. Mr Moore said in relation to a proposal for such a zone in the Newcastle region:
Whether the special free trade zones are the answer or not I am not too sure. I think that is a bit difficult myself.

This is yet another example of Mr Smith not only failing the electors of Bass as their local member but also damaging his already badly damaged reputation amongst his colleagues in the cabinet room. I plan to pursue Mr Smith's free trade zone plan with the relevant ministers to ensure that all Launceston businesses and workers an not disadvantaged. I think that after the next election the electorate of Bass will be a Smith free zone.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to discuss the issue of juvenile justice. I note from the Australian Institute of Criminology's, the AIC's, proceedings of the juvenile crime and juvenile justice conference that it can cost up to $1,000 per week to incarcerate a young offender. Imagine what we could spend that $1,000 on if we were to dedicate it to community services. I would ask that those who argue for cutting income support and welfare and social services for young people seriously consider that figure of $1,000 per week.

speech.para: As the federal campaign looms, I suspect we are going to hear a lot more about the mythical crime wave and calls to get tough on crime—get young people off the streets, presumably with youth curfews or sweep laws. We have heard from one political party that this is one of their policies. We have also heard that we should lock young people up with mandatory sentencing, get them out of town and toughen them up with boot camps, scare them straight with day trips to gaols or shame them with the public wearing of signs. These are all quick fix solutions that soak up public funds and generate headlines, but they have little, if any, impact on crime levels in this country.

We do not need to get tough on youth crime we need to get smart and respond to real research and not the rhetoric of talkback radio. There is no youth crime wave either nationally or within the states or territories. In fact the reality is that young people commit fewer crimes than adults, most youth crime is not violent but is against property and most young people offend only once.

A small number of repeat juvenile offenders commit most crime. The sweeping operations and regulations against all young people do little to address the problems of that small group yet governments continue to enact laws or consider laws which target all young Australians. Efforts to clean up the streets may include criminalising anti-social behaviour such as: being in a public place at night—we saw evidence of laws to tackle this in Western Australia where we had in 1994 operation sweep; being in a shopping mall where private security guards are actually granted the power to exclude particular individuals from the use of certain city sites; wearing of baseball caps backwards, which was mooted by the Premier of New South Wales a few years ago as being anti-social behaviour; or gathering in groups of more than two, evidenced by the proposals relating to anti-gang legislation.

If cleaning up the streets means getting young people off the streets we have to ask: who is public space for? Are not young people members of the public and entitled to use this space? We are in danger of criminalising the young. I know that one set of researchers have coined the term `spatial apartheid' to describe the treatment of young people when it comes to public space.

Originally, the word `juvenile' meant a young person without any negative connotations. Today, juvenile is used either as an insult or interchangeably with young criminal. In practice, the words `juvenile delinquent' are now practically considered a tautology and `juvenile justice' is in danger of becoming an oxymoron. The AIC report says that `we are going dangerously astray in both our overall youth policy in this country', and, particularly, in regard to juvenile justice reform. We are excluding rather than reconnecting young people to society.

Young people who are excluded from their family, employment and education are most likely to be enmeshed in the juvenile justice system. Males are by far the more prominent offenders than females. There are few female offenders which means that there are very few appropriate services to deal with them if they are offending. Homelessness is another factor for many juvenile offenders. Indigenous young people are vastly over represented in both incarceration and unemployment figures. The unemployment rate for indigenous young people is more than twice that of the total number for Australian youth.

The high rates of incarceration of indigenous young people is in effect creating another stolen generation. At the South Australian youth detention centres, the Magill Training Centre and the Cavan Training Centre, Aboriginal young people account for more than one in five of those entering the centres despite the fact that they only represent 1.7 per cent of the total state population. Nationally, 36 per cent of young people in juvenile correction institutions in 1996 were indigenous.

Indigenous young people who accumulate a criminal record on average do so at a younger age than non-Aboriginal children. They generally receive harsher outcomes in the children's court than non-Aboriginal young people, particularly in being sentenced to detention. We need alternatives to incarceration for non-violent offences by those children because those who do end up in custody are more likely to come back again and again unless we can set up a diversion from a well-worn track of poverty, unemployment, despair and crime.

There has been much public condemnation of the Canberra incident where a 12-year-old was forced to wear a T-shirt saying `I am a thief' in the shopping mall from where he stole. Many would not agree with the notion of humiliation punishment, a decision of those concerned. Shaming and labelling works in a small number of first offences when the youth is ashamed of the label `criminal'. Chronic offenders may accept this label however and might even aspire to it. The AIC report said on this matter:
The Brady Bunch kids are a good example of when shaming would work.

We should not judge all alternative disciplining systems for young people on the basis of the Canberra case. Particularly, we should not dismiss the idea of family conferencing. In many cases, it does have great merit. It is based on the principle of restoration and reconciliation.

For the less serious offences, those best placed to decide an appropriate punishment may well be the victim, the offender and their families. They with facilitators meet and attempt to agree on a punishment that makes some recompense, restitution and reparation. This model allows victims the opportunity to participate in the process of dealing with the offender, whereas the usual practice is for crimes to be against the state and the victim to be included merely as a witness. It is hoped that the offender will feel directly accountable for their actions by having their family present and by requiring them to confront the victim.

My home state of South Australia has gone some way down this path with some positive results. The South Australian Young Offenders Act 1993 included the introduction of an up-front police cautioning system which may include community work or compensation, a new diversionary option of family conference and a toughening of outcomes at the court level. Formal prosecution before the youth court is reserved for those repeat offenders who have already been through other options.

Family conferencing can be a very effective option for indigenous young Australians because it involves relevant family members in its justice proceedings. It is the police who are in a position of deciding which is the appropriate option in South Australia. Indigenous communities and their organisations and not just police should have some say as to whether their children would be best served by family conferencing. It is a consultative process. In all states the police hold a great deal of power in dealing with young people, although we often hear reports to the contrary. They act within the laws governments pass but they can also bring to the job their own prejudices.

We do need to improve relations between police and young people, for example, through the police and community youth clubs, youth liaison officers and training which is youth and culturally specific. We do not need `street-sweep' laws which are a recipe for conflict between police and the great majority of young people who stay within the law. A very small group of young people are responsible for multiple offences. There needs to be provision of specialist psychologically based programs for serious repeat offenders, notably sexual and violent offenders. I do not think anyone would disagree with that notion.

The juvenile justice system usually hangs on the myth of punishment and deterrents. Deterrents only work when a person feels that they have something to lose, and many juvenile repeat offenders feel they have nothing to lose. Early intervention by justice and welfare agencies into the troubled lives of young offenders and their families is a better way to address the juvenile crime problem. The peak age for a first offence is 15 to 18 years.

Has the government considered the impact of the CYA legislation, particularly on those young people who do not meet the new obligations to be in training and education? I think there may be some social consequences here that we should consider in the context of the justice debate. The government may save a whole $160 a week in income support to an unemployed teenager, but what will be the cost in pushing young people away from their family and community and, in some cases, into incarceration with its $1,000 a week price tag?

talk.start.para: —I rise this evening to make comment on a recent event in Australia's political history that will forever remain engraved on my mind. I speak of the Constitutional Convention for which I was fortunate enough to represent my party, the Labor Party, as an appointee. I do not want to turn my comments to the actual issues debated at that Constitutional Convention. As a devoted republican, I am obviously welcoming of the outcome. But I turn to a phenomenon that occurred in conjunction with the Constitutional Convention which I think points to a very interesting development in Australian politics and also points to a great opportunity that exists in this country with respect to greater democratic participation by our citizens.

speech.para: The website that was created to promote and convey the information, the words, the substance and even some of the atmosphere of the Constitutional Convention provided an insight for many Australians as to what went on at the Constitutional Convention. The website itself was created by a local company, Safetyweb, for the department. It had a number of remarkable features. First of all, it actually posted the Hansard each day of the convention, which potentially allowed millions of Australians—but I know it was several thousand at least—daily access to the spoken words of the convention. The website featured a whole range of different sites that one could visit, including the biographies of all the participating delegates. It also carried that day's Notice Paper, what was on the agenda, which motions were carried, and the minutes of the meetings as they occurred.

This site had over 70,000 hits during the convention, and we know from the experience of the people managing the site that those visits were not mere scannings—that people actually took the time to have a look at what was being said. While the convention made great radio and attracted a lot of attention through the mainstream media, including the electronic and print media, I believe the website assisted in the capturing of the spirit of the convention for the broader Australian public.

The convention itself, as I said at the time, was perhaps the greatest exercise in civics education that we have seen in recent times in this country. To be able to convey that experience in this new medium that we know is particularly accessible to young people can teach us many lessons about the operation of this place. Here in Parliament House the information services are doing an amazing job in taking the parliament to the people on-line. Recent developments have meant an even more upgraded on-line service with the transfer of committee reports and Hansard to the Internet for general reference for, particularly, students conducting their own research but, more recently, greater involvement and participation by people who are interested in a specific area of policy or legislation being discussed, or who are just curious about how our democracy works.

The design of a site is particularly important. It needs to be easy to use. It needs to be easily followed. It is too easy for technology to become intimidating for those unfamiliar with it. So more time, thought and resource being placed into designing effective websites so that people can easily access information is, I believe, a great investment in the enhancement of participation by people generally in our political processes.

Political parties too have not been slack in seeing what an opportunity the Internet presents. I can speak for my own party, who have taken great pride in establishing a comprehensive information-based website that is available as a resource for people curious about our party and our policies. The growth of Internet usage is something that is continually on my mind, both in terms of the potential it holds to enhance participation in our democracy generally and as a general tool of empowerment for those in our community.

One of the most critical policy aspects of this phenomenon that is occurring is, of course, this question of access to the Internet and the equity that is a must if we are to prevent the growing gap between the information haves and have-nots in our country. We know from the Australian Bureau of Statistics that the richer you are in Australia, the more likely you are to have Internet access. Does this mean that perhaps your opportunity to participate in an on-line democratic forum or exercise must be contingent upon your wealth?

There is no more pressing policy issue in the area of information technology than addressing this one of equity of access to the Internet. It must take priority if we are to utilise developments in information technology to the benefit of the whole of Australian society. Unless we do this, the success of the Constitutional Convention and its on-line presentation can be measured only in terms of a particular grouping within our society, defined by its advantageous economic status. Would it not be a great indictment upon an Australian government if it did not specifically address these equity issues when they were able to?

Statistically, the number of young people using the Internet is growing exponentially every year. The most comprehensive statistics on the growth of Internet usage predictably come from the US, and the most remarkable feature of these indicators is still the phenomenal growth of usage.

In closing, I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the site for the Constitutional Convention. Now that senators and members have Internet access in their parliamentary offices, I only hope those who have not taken the opportunity to access it will do so, just to experience the Constitutional Convention experience of 70,000-odd Australians. The convention's home page can be found at www.dpmc.gov.au/convention/hansard. There are other buttons available on that home page that can take you to reports and resolutions, notice papers and speakers lists. And to help facilitate the reportage of the spoken word, there is even a button entitled `press releases' that everyone's public statements were placed on.

The Constitutional Convention site is just one example of a remarkable phenomenon that is taking place. The phenomenon has the potential to involve all Australians or it has the potential to marginalise most and benefit only a few. This policy challenge, I believe, is one of the most dramatic that is facing governments in today's age.

talk.start.para: —I was very interested to listen to my colleague Senator Lundy talking about information technology and the Constitutional Convention. If I had a request for Senator Lundy—particularly after listening to that address—it would relate to the fact that the last piece of user friendliness that still has to be developed is easy to reproduce addresses for the e-mail and Internet. Fix that for me, Senator Lundy, and I will thank you forever.

speech.para: What I wanted to talk about tonight was a visit I made last week to Cobar. The week before that we had the opportunity in our caucus economics and living standards committee to hear from a delegation of miners from Cobar. We heard from them the consequences of the closure of the CIA mine in Cobar and the devastating effect that has had on that community.

Cobar is a town of between 5,000 and 7,000 people—it depends on how people present it—and it is a pretty proud, close-knit and supportive community. The community is reeling from the closure of that mine and, in particular, so are the miners, the workers and the staff who have all had the rug pulled from under them. At the moment, by conservative estimates, the mine and its owners—particularly Ashanti—have got away with some $9 million of workers' money. That is money that is owed to them for their annual leave, their holiday leave and their retrenchment packages. Any decent contract between staff and an employer means that that money is not something workers suddenly thought of at the last minute; it is a contractual obligation that the employers have to pay those workers.

I believe this is a very devastating and significant disaster for Cobar, but it is not without precedent in other parts of Australia. We have heard of the closure of the Woodlawn mine in Goulburn, with again something like $6 million outstanding to the workers there—though Woodlawn, I have to say, have approached their responsibilities in quite a different way to Ashanti. Nevertheless, they have dudded the workers in their mine of $6 million, which they say they will try to pay, unlike the case with Ashanti and the CIA mine in Cobar. We have heard of the meatworkers at Grafton. That firm went insolvent and, once again, the workers have been dudded of the many millions of dollars owing to them. A nursing home in Queensland equally has closed its business and got away with millions of dollars of money owing to workers.

We are beginning to see a pattern of behaviour here—a pattern of behaviour that is a deliberate flouting of the rights and contractual obligations of the people in employ. It is a behaviour that most reminds me of the robber barons of the 19th century—that is, `It's my money. I'll take it and go.' This is illustrated in a particularly devastating way in Cobar.

We had two meetings in the town. The first was with a significant group of women, mainly the wives of the workers on the mine, but not all. The women were either in small business or partners or wives of small business people who provided all sorts of provisions to the mine—from equipment, to bricks, to food, to whatever. All of those small businesses of course are completely without contracts, and they have just fallen over completely.

The impact on the community is that those families now have workers who are pretty broken and lacking in confidence. The husbands in those families are very depressed and despondent, and they are concerned most immediately about tomorrow's money—where is it coming from so they can pay for the food, the mortgage and the clothing for their families, and where on earth are they going to get more work?

Some of those families who have been able to access social security—and many have not, and I will come to that—are now finding that they are trying to live on social security payments when the husband has had to go interstate looking for work. If you think it is difficult managing on unemployment benefits when husband, wife and children are living in the one home, try managing on that same amount of money when the husband has actually gone to Perth or Queensland looking for work. There are the accommodation costs, the travel costs and the family at home still trying to hang together on the smell of an oil rag with what is left of those payments. Those families are doing it very hard.

Some of the families have had a higher income, and they have used some of their spare money to set up some kind of investment—whether it is superannuation or other investments in property—for their retirement. They now find themselves, as has often been the case when we have considered social security, asset rich but income poor and not eligible for social security benefits.

Many hundreds of the people at the women's meeting and then later at the very large public meeting at the bowling club—mainly the miners and many of the women again—pointed out that, if the town had been flooded or if they had had a drought, either of those situations would have enabled them to be described as in a disaster situation and eligible for disaster relief. This is a disaster for that town and those families, but they are eligible for nothing special.

Sometimes, particularly in drought situations, farmers have been eligible for special disaster assistance when they have found themselves asset rich but income poor, and I am certainly going to be writing to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, to ask if some consideration can be given to families in this disaster. It is nothing to do with the miners, but many livelihoods and families have been affected and now that town is reeling from that blow.

talk.start.para: —Bet you they don't have family trusts!

—I do not know about that, Senator, but I do know that many of those families are in terrible straits. We also know that in that town unemployment has gone from three per cent to 30 per cent more or less overnight. None of these people are trying to be out of work. All of these people were decent hard-working people. They were committed to trying to manage, as well as they could, for their families. They now find themselves on the unemployment list and they find that they are getting no assistance wherever they turn.

speech.para: A delegation met with Prime Minister Howard and he promised to respond to them to see if there was any way in which a loan could be taken out to assist the families or some other arrangement could be made. So far, I am advised, Mr Howard has made no contact back to that group and it is over two weeks later. He promised to respond within two weeks; he has not done so. Those families are the battlers that Mr Howard promised to support. They are the families that Mr Howard says he barracks for, and yet he is able to do nothing—to this point—that could assist them.

Today, in the other place, my colleague Janice Crosio introduced a private member's bill to ensure that in the future workers' moneys of this sort would never be able to be abused in this way; denied to the workers. Unfortunately, that bill is not able to be retrospective. But, so far, the advice I have is that the government is not minded to support it. If they are serious about helping this group of families, this group of struggling, genuine decent contributors to our society and to that township, then they should seriously look—and I appeal to Mr Howard to look again—at ways in which he might help these families. Let us see our Prime Minister put his money—or the taxpayers' support and money—where his mouth has been to this point.

Those families are dealing with a number of other blows in that community too. People said with cynicism, `Well, I suppose as well as everything else we'll have the banks closing.' The day after we were there, the state bank in Cobar closed and is now leaving the town. The school has gone from 460 pupils to 410 and under New South Wales classification it has now been classified down. None of these things are due to any behaviour on behalf of the staff, the employees, the workers in that town, but all the devastation that has come their way is due to a high-handed, very illegal and I think morally reprehensible act on behalf of the employers. The owners of the mine, particularly Ashanti, have made devastation in their lives and I do believe it is a challenge to Mr Howard to deliver on some of that support. He has not so far.

The miners are waiting and they are not going to forget if he fails to support them immediately or even, importantly, to support Janice Crosio's bill to make sure that this kind of devastation never happens to the miners in Cobar, to the workers in nursing homes, to meat workers in other businesses, to workers in this country who up until now expected their contractual obligations would be fulfilled by the employers. It is time we put paid to this kind of robbery.

talk.start.para: —In the few minutes remaining I want to bring to the attention of the Senate a matter that was referred to me last week concerning the non-payment of superannuation contributions to a number of employees of a company called Sunland Security Services in Queensland. Apparently, the employees concerned have not been paid in respect of their superannuation entitlements under the superannuation guarantee for at least the 1996-97 financial year. This obviously concerns not just the employee who has contacted me but all of the employees, both current and former, of this particular company.

speech.para: Why does it concern the employees? Firstly, superannuation will be a major component of the retirement income of Australians in future. Secondly, whilst the moneys are not paid, and if the company is experiencing some financial difficulty, there is certainly a fear in the employees' minds that they may never see their money. Thirdly, it is certainly arguable, and I think highly likely, that, given the non-payment of the superannuation moneys, the death and disability insurance coverage of the employees has lapsed.

It was also brought to my attention that the tax office has been made aware of this situation on a number of occasions by a number of employees, both former and current, certainly over the last nine or 10 months. Unfortunately, the employees, according to the information provided to me, have not received any response of substance about when they are likely to receive their money from the tax office.

I did write to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, about this matter last week. I was also able to discuss it, at lunchtime today, with the owner of the company, Sunland Security Services. She explained to me that there were some financial difficulties—that the company had been disadvantaged by the bankruptcy of a subcontractor that occurred at least 18 months ago, and that that had created some financial difficulties. The owner of Sunland Security Services has assured me today that she believes the superannuation entitlements of current and former employees will be paid by the end of April, and that correspondence has been entered into with the tax office and the payments will be made.

I am sure that the employees, both current and former, of the security firm, will be pleased to hear this and certainly pleased to receive their moneys. I can appreciate and understand the financial difficulties that the particular company has experienced. I certainly accept the assurances of the owner that the moneys will be paid. I think it is regrettable that the moneys for the period of at least the financial year have been outstanding for some time. This has obviously caused some considerable worry and concern to both current and former employees and this is an unfortunate example. I accept there are some difficulties that the company has been experiencing, and I also accept that there are other cases likely to be of a more serious nature that exist elsewhere in the community.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Does the Minister agree with tables on p.83 of the Economist magazine of 23 August 1997 that indicate that Australian business faces the highest real interest rates of any Organisation for Economic Co-operation
and Development (OECD) country; if not, why not.
(2) Why has the Government refused to endorse the Wallis inquiry recommendation that small business be given access to the Banking Ombudsman scheme.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The tables in the Economist magazine refer to nominal interest rates.

Real interest rates are a theoretical construct which cannot be observed directly. Conceptually, real interest rates are calculated by discounting nominal interest rates by the average expected inflation rate over the duration of the term of the loan. There is, however, no precise method for estimating such inflation expectations. While for short term rates the current inflation rate is sometimes used as an approximation, considerable caution should be exercised in drawing any conclusions based on this approach.

International comparisons of nominal interest rates are also subject to several limitations. Rates may not be comparable if they relate to different segments of the market, or if they fail to take account of different levels of risk or different terms. In addition, different structures for fees and charges are also relevant in considering the significance of such comparisons. These considerations are particularly relevant when comparing interest rates charged to business borrowers.

(2) On 11 October 1997, the Prime Minister wrote to the banking industry expressing the Government's view that the Banking Code of Practice and the industry-operated Australian Banking Industry Ombudsman scheme and alternative dispute resolution mechanisms should be extended to small business.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Is it a role of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) to ensure that equity investors in projects such as the M2 Motorway and the Eastern Distributor (Sydney) and City Link (Melbourne) are properly protected against concocted, biased or misleading information, particularly when institutions such as superannuation funds invest in such projects.
(2) (a) How does the ASC carry out this role; and (b) is every prospectus reviewed or only those about which complaints are made.

(3) What tests or criteria is a prospectus required to meet to demonstrate that information such as traffic projections, which is critical to the financial performance of road projects, is accurate and reliable.
(4) What surveillance was carried out in the case of the three projects referred to in (1), to ensure that superannuation funds and other investors were property protected.
(5) Did the ASC receive any advice that something was seriously wrong with the M2 Motorway prospectus; if so: (a) from whom; and (b) when.

(6) What investigation or reaction did the ASC make to the float of the Infrastructure Trust of Australia (ITA) Group, set up by the Macquarie Bank, which involves the Eastern Distributor, Transurban City Link, and the M2 and M5 motorways.
(7) Has Mr Moore-Wilton or any other officer of the Government made contact with the ASC regarding: (a) the M2 Motorway prospectus; (b) the ITA Group prospectus; or (c) related matters.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) (a) The role of the ASC in prospectus review is to ensure that adequate information is disclosed to allow investors and their advisers to make an informed assessment of the merits of an investment. The measures available to the ASC in carrying out this role include:

(i) refusing to register a prospectus if, at the time the document is reviewed for registration, the ASC is of the opinion that the prospectus contravenes the prospectus provisions of the Corporations Law ('the Law') (principally Division 2 of Part 7.12 of the Law); contains a false or misleading statement or that there is an omission from the prospectus;

(ii) issuing a stop order on a prospectus where it appears to the ASC that the prospectus contravenes, in a substantial respect, the prospectus provisions of the Law or where it contains false, misleading or deceptive statements or material misrepresentations; and

(iii) investigating suspected breaches of the Law in relation to the issue of prospectuses. In cases where there have been material breaches in the rules of prospectus disclosure, particularly where investors have suffered losses, the ASC has at its disposal civil and criminal powers of enforcement.
Under the Law, investors also have rights of action to recover any loss or damages against persons involved in the preparation of a defective prospectus.

(2) (b) The Law places primary responsibility on the issuer to prepare a prospectus which complies with the legislation. Registrable prospectuses are subject to examination by ASC staff to determine whether there are obvious false or misleading statements or omissions which would warrant refusal of registration. I am advised that, at that stage, ASC does not generally request further information to verify statements made in the prospectus.

In carrying out its role in ensuring prospectuses comply with the Law, I am advised that the ASC places emphasis on its post-vetting program, which involves a more detailed review of selected prospectuses after registration. In a post-vet, underlying documents are examined to ensure information in the prospectus can be substantiated. Selection for post-vetting is based on an assessment of risks and other intelligence information including complaints. The ASC regularly post-vets prospectuses whether or not specific complaints have been received.

(3) Traffic forecasts are complex and require specialised expertise in their preparation. Their reliability is usually subject to various factors and assumptions. Promoters often rely on the traffic expert's reports or advice in making the forecasts. I am advised by the ASC that it is concerned to ensure that the basis of the forecasts and the associated risks are disclosed in the prospectus so that investors can assess the reliability of the forecasts.

Although the Law provides for civil and criminal liabilities for promoters in relation to false or misleading prospectuses, there are various defences available to promoters, including reasonable reliance on experts. Thus in any enforcement action, it is not sufficient to show (in some cases, with the benefit of hindsight) that a forecast is incorrect. It is necessary to prove that the forecast could not have been made on a reasonable basis at the time it was made.
In August 1997, the ASC issued Practice Note 67 `Financial Forecasts in Prospectuses' to give guidance about the standards it expects of disclosures with a director's or expert's financial forecast.
(4) I am advised that the ASC carried out the following surveillance in relation to the three projects to which the question refers:

(a) M2 Motorway—The prospectus for the M2 Motorway was subject to detailed post-vetting by the ASC shortly after its registration in late 1994. The ASC subsequently reviewed a number of complaints received in relation to the prospectus.

(b) Eastern Distributor—A post-vet was carried out in August 1997 following the receipt by the ASC of complaints about the forecast traffic volume and financial viability of the Eastern Distributor contained in the prospectus of the Infrastructure Trust of Australia Group ('ITA').

(c) Transurban City Link—A limited post-vet of the Transurban City Link prospectus was undertaken after its registration in February 1996. One complaint was received by the ASC regarding non-disclosure of pending litigation.
Based on assessment of information available at the time, the ASC decided not to take enforcement action on the complaints in relation to each of the three projects.

(5) (a) I am advised that the ASC received a number of complaints in relation to the M2 Motorway prospectus in the period November 1994 to September 1997. The source of those complaints is confidential.

(b) I am advised that a search of the ASC's records reveals that written complaints were received between November 1994 and September 1997. In addition, discussions were held with complainants in November 1994 and February 1997.

(6) I am advised that a general post-vet of the ITA prospectus was carried out in November 1996 and further post-vetting was carried out in August 1997 on the traffic forecast of the Eastern Distributor as outlined in the answer to question 4(b) above.

(7) I am advised that a search of the ASC's files in relation to the M2 Motorway prospectus, the ITA prospectus and related complaints files has not revealed any approaches from any officer of the Government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 20 November 1997:

question.para: With reference to the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 which passed the Senate on 25 September 1997:
(1) Has the department commenced arrangements in anticipation of the enactment of this legislation; if so, what have been those arrangements.
(2) Has any office equipment or computer hardware or software been purchased in anticipation of the enactment of the bill; if so, how much money has been spent, and on what.
(3) After the Act comes into force, how long is it anticipated before administrative arrangements will be in place to give efficacy to the Act.

talk.start.para: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: First, let me apologise to Senator Murray for not replying to his question soonex. Unfortunately, this results from an administrative oversight in my Department. In relation to the questions asked, I am advised as follows:

(1) The Department has commenced arrangements in anticipation of the enactment of this legislation. Those arrangements include recruiting some core staff in the Office of Legislative Drafting to develop computer and administrative systems associated with the Federal Register of Legislative Instruments.

The backcapturing of existing instruments commenced in September 1996 and is well advanced in respect of the Statutory Rules series, in accordance with the early backcapturing provisions in the Bill. The material backcaptured to date is on
the Legislative Instruments Database (a precursor to the Federal Register) and is accessible on the Window on the Law site on the Internet (URL: http://law.gov.au).
(2) The Department bought, under contract, an integrated, computerised system specially designed for the Federal Register for approximately $1.1 million.

(3) Before the Act could commence regulations need to be made and the drafting of these cannot be completed until the final content of the Act is known. It is expected that final administrative arrangements will be in place within 3 months of enactment of the Bill.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 5 February 1998

question.para: (1) For the calendar year 1997, what financial and other savings, and what benefits, have accrued to Victoria as a result of unifying its industrial relations system with that of the federal system.
(2) With this as a guide, is it possible to extrapolate, on an annual basis, equivalent savings by State, if this action were followed by every State.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

answer.para: (1) The precise savings to the Victorian Government for the calendar year 1997 are not known. However, based on discussions between officials prior to the referral of Victoria's industrial relations powers to the Commonwealth, it was estimated that it was costing the Victorian Government in excess of $8.7m per annum to provide the functions that were the subject of the referral.
The benefits of a unified industrial relations system in Victoria are:
. a single more efficient and less costly system with one set of rules to replace the legalism and complications that arise from systems running side-by-side and overlapping
. easier access to the agreement-making choices provided by the federal system through certified agreements and Australian workplace agreements

. an effective and fair transition process from the dual system to the single system—employment agreements under the former Victorian State law are given continuing effect and the safety net protections are maintained and these functions are now not being performed by the State

It is also worthy to note that the Victorian Government has formally advised the Labour Ministers' Council at its meeting on 21 November 1997 of its continued support for the referral and of the benefits which have accrued to the State. The Joint Communique issued by the Labour Ministers' Council following that meeting included, inter alia the following:

"Victorian Minister Hallam confirmed the Victorian Government's continuing support for the historic decision, taken 12 months ago, to refer Victoria's industrial relations powers to the Commonwealth. Minister Hallam said the referral had benefited employers and employees alike and had successfully introduced a seamless and user friendly State and Federal industrial relations system in Victoria."

The savings which accrue from these benefits are not restricted to savings to Government or taxpayers. Private sector employers and employees are nett beneficiaries given that the industrial relations systems have been established for their common benefit. It is not possible to quantify the direct and indirect savings to the private sector given the wide variety of potential and actual users of the system. Savings to the private sector can, however, be grouped into categories which include:
. speed of establishing rights and obligations—by having one point of reference for administrative services such as enquiries and advice on wages and conditions
. accuracy of establishing rights and obligations—by eliminating uncertainty or confusion created by dual systems of award regulation or agreement making
. simplicity in investigation, compliance and enforcement measures

. expedition in agreement making and dispute resolution—by having one point of reference for access to services of the Industrial Relations Commission (including in dismissal matters and disputes) and one jurisdiction for agreement making
. less technicality in dispute resolution and agreement making—by eliminating preliminary jurisdictional points of law based on cross jurisdictional issues
. less cost in dispute resolution—by eliminating costly litigation relating to jurisdictional overlap
. less potential for disputes over wages and conditions—by a single jurisdictional regulation within individual businesses and the elimination of dual coverage of single workplaces

In addition, the standing of the workplace relations system in the eyes of employers (particularly small business), employees and the community at large is enhanced by a single point of service delivery, rather than stakeholders being referred from one jurisdiction to the other for information or assistance in dispute resolution or agreement making.

(2) The Commonwealth does not have access to more detailed information from all of the other States to extrapolate estimated cost savings from a unitary industrial relations system. The quantification of savings would be likely to vary in each State as each State system provides a service to differing numbers of employers and employees. There would however be common features in many of the categories of savings, including the features identified in answer to question (1) above.
